properties.text: This day, Mr. Richard I Morsell called on me with his Son, and made me the Annual payment, of three-hundred dollars, due this day, according to our agreement offor the purchase of the House which I purchased of Daniel Baker, and he also paid in advance the remaining Sum of one hundred and one dollars and fifty-five cents, which would be due, on the first of April 1848. to complete the final payment, deducting therefrom six dollars and ten cents, being the interest, which would be due, on the sum remaining to be paid, as the final payment, on the first of April next The whole sum that I received from him this day therefore was three-hundred and ninety-four dollars, and sixty five cents; for which I gave a receipt in full, and am now to give him, a Deed in Fee of the House—

I made a draft, of a Deed in Fee, to Richard I. Morsell, of the House which I purchased of the Revd. Daniel Baker— I received a Letter, from Milnor Rudulph, of Memphis Tennessee, dated 15th. March 1847. Yesterday I received, a Letter, signed H. Holtz Chairman, being a mock account of a meeting of Planters, at Dancyville Tennessee and of certain ridiculous resolutions, passed at that meeting, to be forwarded to me, with the request, that I would urge the immediate interference, in their behalf— I rose this day, more unwell than I have been for several months, and sent for Dr. Thomas, who ordered new prescriptions for me to take, and I took a morning ride in the Carriage, with Elizabeth. C Adams, and Mrs. John— After which, I found myself somewhat better— I sent also to Mr. Alexander Borland the Carpenter, and directed him to make, several boxes, to Ship the Cargo Folio News papers in Volumes, for my residence at Quincy— I had some other business to attend to, but postponed it, as it was, Good Friday—

Ezra R. Keefer for Charles Wilson Commission Merchant at Alexandria brought me a Certificate signed by . . . Mantz. Treasurer of Frederick City Hotel. dated the 26th. of March 1846, that there appears from the Books of the Frederick City Hotel to be thirty two dollars, and fifty cents standing to the credit of John Adams, for Dividends due, to which certificate is subjoined, a note in the following words—A power of Attorney, and a simple order to transfer, is all that is necessary the order to be in favour of Michael Zimmerman I had agreed, with Mr. Wilson, to transfer the five Shares, for one hundred and fifty dollars, and thirty two dollars and fifty cents, for the Dividends standing due thereon— I accordingly drew up a Power of Attorney, to Michael Zimmerman, authorizing him to make the transfer and received, from Mr. Keefer, for Mr. Charles Wilson, a check on the Potomac Bank at Alexandria, for one-hundred and eighty-two dollars and fifty cents payable to me, on my Order—

Easter Sunday— I attended at Saint Johns Church, morning and afternoon, and heard Mr. Pyne, read the Services of the day, and preach from both parts of the day from Colossians, 3.1. “If ye then be risen with Christ seek those things which are above, where Christ sitteth on the right hand of God”— After the afternoon service, I rode in the carriage, with Elizabeth. C. Adams, and Mrs. John Adams, into Georgetown— Mr. and Mrs. Frye were here part of the evening.

This morning I executed the power of Attorney, to Michael Zimmerman, to transfer the five shares, in the Frederick City Hotel, standing in the name of my deceased son John, and delivered the same to Ezra R. Keefer, for Charles Wilson, Commission Merchant at Alexandria—and I deposited in the Bank of the Metropolis, the check on the Bank of Potomac at Alexandria, which was there received and entered to my credit as cash— The papers relating to this transaction are placed, among my bundle of Deeds and Vouchers—

I, this day, and my wife executed and acknowledged, before two Justices of the Peace for the County of Washington, and District of Columbia, Sam D King, and A Tho Smith, a Deed in fee, to Richard. I. Morsell, of the Estate, which I purchased, of Revd. Daniel Baker, and I delivered the Deed of the same to the said Richard. I. Morsell. keeping a copy of the same Deed and of its acknowledgement, which I put upon file among my deeds and vouchers—

List of Deeds, and other private Vouchers. belonging to John Quincy Adams. kept in a separate Bundle, at Washington—tied up in a calico cover—together, with a copy of the last Will, of the said John Quincy Adams, executed at Boston, on the 18th. of January last, another copy of which, is in the possession, of Charles. Francis. Adams, constituted Sole Executor of the said Will—
Mary Louisa being unwell this day, our Diary was suspended—as also the list of Private Deeds and Vouchers—
We resumed today, the list of Deeds and Vouchers—

I attended in the morning Divine Service at the Unitarian Church—where Mr. Longfellow preached. from Phillippians 3.13. “But this one thing I do, forgetting those things which are behind, and reaching forth, unto those things which are before. 14. I press toward the mark,”— In the afternoon, at St. Johns Church, I heard Mr. Tillinghast from Providence Rhode Island read the prayers for the first Sunday after Easter and preach from Luke 2.14. “Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace good will towards men.” A sermon, with which I was greatly pleased, being the song of the Angels at the Birth of Jesus. the most wonderful, the most sublime, and the most cheering passage, in the Holy Scriptures. After the Afternoon Service, I took a ride with Mrs. John Adams and Elizabeth, and Mary Louisa. We passed the evening without visitors. The news was received of the surrender of the City of Vera Cruz and the Castle of St. Juan D’Ulloa to the American Army on the 27th. of March under the command of General Winfield Scott—

Visit this morning from Phillip R. Fendall Esq. We continue to take minutes, of Deeds and Vouchers, for preservation. Last evening about ten there was a fire in our neighborhood, in the house occupied by. and this morning about eight oclock there was an other in the house nearly opposite ours, on the other side of the street. belonging to Joseph Abbott and occupied by Mr. Heiss, one of the Editors of the Union newspaper— They were both extinguished with out much damage. Received from my son, Charles F. Adams, a draft from L. M. Stone Cashier of the Merchants Bank at Boston, payable at one days sight, without grace, for one thousand two hundred dollars, endorsed payable to Richard Smith, Cashier of the Bank of Metropolis, and this day taken up by me— This Bill, was to pay, for five shares, in the stock of the Old Massachusetts Bank. in Boston invested in the name of Mrs. Mary Catherine Adams, my daughter— Received by her, in exchange for 1000 dollars, of Washington City Corporation six per cent Stock, standing in my name, but belonging to her. and also, for five shares in the Frederick City Hotel, which stood in the name of her husband deceased, but which I as his Administrator, recently sold, for one hundred and eighty two fifty cents. The two sums, amounting to 1182 dollars, and fifty cents, leaving a balance of 40 dollars, charged to me, by my Son, in his account— The Letter from my Son, and the draft taken up by me are placed among my private Vouchers.

13. VII.  I have received from George. H. Colton, a Letter dated the 3d. New York, enclosed with which, was an Article, for the next Number of his American Review upon Executive patronage and National expenditure Upon which he requests, remarks from me— I answered the Letter of George. H. Colton, with remarks on the Article. respecting the power of removing Public Officers—

I took to the Office of the Commissioner of Pensions a Letter from Wm. Ellis of Dedham of the 18th. February last relating to the Claims, of John Endicott, and others, and of Peter Dunbar— Also a Letter from Elisha. G. Tucker, Boston 26th. February last, on the Claim of the widow of J. B. Brereton. Also the Letter of Jason Holbrook Randolph, 25th. February 1847, relating to the claim of the heirs of Ichabod Holbrook, for commutation Pay and Bounty Lands. Also the Letter of Wm. K. Hoyt, no. 24. Mc.Dougal Street, New York, 16th. February 1847, and the Letter of Jonathan Wild, of Braintree, 12th. April 1847. relating to the Claim of Deborah Wild for a pension.

Mary Louisa went with a party to Baltimore, to see the Viennoise dancers. morning ride to the Clerks Office of the House at the Capitol. Afternoon walk. Evening visit, from Mr. Abbott and Mr. Longfellow preacher at the Unitarian Church.

Mrs. John Adams received a message from her daughter Mary Louisa at Baltimore not to expect her home this day— No morning walk— Received a Bill of lading for eight boxes of books and papers, shipped at Georgetown, in the Schooner May E. A. Nickerson Master by John. Q. Adams, Quincy to be delivered to Charles. F. Adams, Boston— Paid check 114. Bank of the Metropolis, to Haslup and Weeden $28.87 also check 115. to T. F. Semmes $23.50 cents for a fifteen gallon Cask of Madeira wine— Afternoon ride—Mr. Larned and Miss Elizabeth Johnson were here this evening

Lieut Joseph H. Adams, here— Arrived in the Levant, from the Pacific at Norfolk. Virginia— Mary Louisa returned from Baltimore— Mrs. William. B. Kibby and Mrs. George Parker came for a contribution for the Protestant Orphan Asylum— Mr Frye was here this evening and left with me, a Letter from me, to him, dated the 28th. November 1837. stating that the Deeds of the Columbian Mills were then missing from the Bundle—

29. VI.  I went to the Pension Office, with a certificate from J. G. Palfrey Secretary of State of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, dated February 1844—attesting the service of Peter Dunbar from 29th. July 1780. to 11th. of August 1780—which exactly completed the six months, and Mr. Edwards said, he would make out the certificate— I went to the Franklin Insurance Company Office, where I was informed, that there are no meetings of the Stockholders, but that there will be a meeting of the Directors of the Company a Committee of whom will report to them, a statement of the affairs of the Company, and the half yearly Dividend to be made on Monday next, 3d. of May I took the list of the Directors at the present time. Election is held, the first week in June—

Mr. Parkman son of George Parkman of Boston was here. Lieut Joseph. H. Adams left us, to return to his Ship the Levant, at Norfolk Virginia. His brother Isaac Hull Adams, went with him. Mary Louisa, went with Mr. James Buchanan the Secretary of State, to the President and Mrs. Polk’s reception evening Party—

The Corner stone, of the Smithsonian Edifice, was laid— I did not attend to witness it— We called at Coleman’s, to visit Mrs. George Parkman, her son, and daughter, but they were out and we left cards— I walked partly home from the Capitol—and walked again after dinner— Elizabeth. C. Adams left us, and went to Mrs. Campbells— I received from the Commissioner of Pensions, a Pension Certificate, for the heirs of Peter Dunbar. and enclosed it to Mr. Ellis Dedham—

2. VI.  Heard Mr. Morrison, at the Unitarian Church, preach from Matthew 6.25—“Is not the life, more than meat, and the body than raiment.” And after dinner, at St John’s Church heard the Revd. Mr. Tillinghast. from Gallatians 6.14—“But God forbid, that I should glory save in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ—by whom the world is crucified unto me, and I unto the world.” I was much pleased with this Discourse— One of Mr. Pyne’s children died this morning. Mrs. Goods daughter, Jane, was married in Church this afternoon, after the evening service, to an Englishman named Mellon—

I took to the Pension Office, a certificate received from Mr. Jonathan Wild, that his mother Deborah Wild, is yet living—which certificate is necessary to obtain her Claim for a Pension— Mrs. Parkman and her son, visited us last evening and left this morning for Baltimore— Her daughter, is in very delicate health, and was too unwell to come out— This excursion to the South, is principally occasioned by the state of her health— Mr. Frye was here this evening, and left with me, his account current, as my Agent and Attorney from the 28th. June 1844. to the 18th. of April 1847. presenting a nominal balance to be accounted for in my favor, of $281,74 cents, with a note stating that this balance is altogether nominal as there are outstanding liabilities against him to a much greater amount. Such as Taxes, that have become due since the last were paid— Indispensable repairs, on property, expenses of collections, including the fees and commissions of Lawyers, Marshalls, Clerks of Courts, Magistrates, Constables, and collectors and sundry small incidental expenses necessarily incurred by him, not heretofore charged in any accounts since the commencement of his Agency for me, on the 18th. of May 1835. This statement is furnished me for the purpose only of informing me, of the monies actually  received and the principal expenditures, made during the period embraced in it, And it presents a picture of real Estate, consisting of dwelling houses, and Mills, which cost upwards of $30,000 proving, if not an absolute burden, scarcely a perceptible profit— My own house rent, clogged with continual expenses of repairs, is the only profit, I have derived, from my large real Estate, in the City of Washington—which has cost me, at least one hundred thousand dollars.

I did not notice, that Mr. John P. Kennedy of Baltimore, was here, last Friday— The following is a copy of a Letter from me to Mr. Frye, dated Washington 28. Novr. 1837—  Nathaniel Frye. Esqr. Washington  Among the papers in the bundle, which Mrs. Adams had left with you, and which she brought back the day before yesterday, I have found the obligation of Johnson Hellen to his sister, but not the certificate of Stock in the Bank of Washington. Mrs. Adams has taken Johnson’s obligation, and will send a deliver it to you—  But there are missing from the bundle all the Deeds of the Columbian Mills, and the plot of the land with them— Last Spring when I went home I separated my Deeds of property here from those of property in Massachusetts, taking the last home with me, and leaving the others here— That is the bundle which Mrs. Adams left with you. In making the separation I may accidentally have put up the Deeds of the Columbian Mills, with the Massachusetts vouchers, which I left with my Son— I will write to him to enquire— I did write to him to ascertain if the obligation of Johnson Hellen and the certificate of Stock in the Washington Bank were not there— He answered they were not— Happily Johnson’s Obligation is now found— The certificate is still missing—  Affectionately yours  The Original of this Letter is returned to Mr. Frye—  Mr. Lewis Johnson was here yesterday, and left with me two Letters, for Mr. John Otis of West-Barnstable, to be forwarded by the mail— I was at the Franklin Insurance Company Office, and received a Dividend of 7 1/2 per cent for the half year and left there, a note of $4000, to Mrs. Mary. C. Adams, endorsed by her, instead of one, for the same sum, dated the 21st. of March 1827, to William. S. Nichols, taken up and cancelled— A security contingent note on two hundred shares of the Stock standing to my credit, on the Books of the Company. The responsibility of the whole note being upon me, and my property— Mary Louisa dined at Mrs. Swift’s being the Birth day of Miss Howard of Springfield— Capt Casey was here this evening— His sister Miss Casey sent me a bouquet of flowers. I received from the Committee of Arrangements, an invitation to witness the display of fire works, at the illumination next Saturday

I enclosed to Mr. Jonathan Wild, the two Widow’s Pension Certificates, for his mother Deborah Wild of Braintree and answered, the invitation to witness the Fire works on Saturday, which I declined, on account of my health— Dr. Thomas was here, having been several days himself detained by indisposition— Mrs. Goods continues confined to her room— We had evening visits, from Mr. and Mrs. Seaton— Morning ride to the Navy Yard and afternoon walk till sun set— Mr. Kavasales, stationed as a Navy Chaplain at the Navy Yard, in this City, called here to see me two or three days since—

Mrs. Goods, has recovered, though I this morng rose from bed and dressed myself without assistance, which I perhaps, shall never do again—being a complete cripple, for the remnant of my days— Elizabeth— C. Adams returned from Mrs. Campbell’s. I gave a check, for one hundred dollars, to Mrs. Mary C. Adams, on account of Household expenses—and received myself, the money at the Bank, in five dollar Bills— I walked before dinner, and rode after dinner, with the Ladies, until about sunset— The news came, of a famous victory by General Scott, near Jalapa, on the 18th. of the last month. I have ceased making fire in my bed chamber— We read in the evening, several chapters, in Walpole’s Memoirs, of the reign of George the third—

Day of rejoicing for the victories— Cannonade and ringing of bells, in the morning.— Walk round the Patent Office Building before dinner, and ride round Meridian Hill, towards Sunset. Major Graham, Mr. Whipple and Mr. Reynolds, paid us morning visits— Illumination and the Fire works in the evening for sundry victories, to which was added that of Cerro Gordo on the 18th. of last month

Heard this morning at the Unitarian Church, Mr. Bellows from Massachusetts. A brother, of the gentleman of the Same name from New York— His Discourse was from Matthew 9.17. “Neither do men put new wine into old bottles, else the bottles break and the wine runneth and the bottles perish; but they put new wine into new bottles and both are preserved.” Mr. Bellows, is a Sensible preacher, though not equal to his brother. In the afternoon, at St John’s Church Mr. Pyne read the evening Service, for the fifth Sunday after Easter, but instead of a Sermon, delivered an Address to the children, of his Congregation, which I did not stay to hear— He had administered the Communion in the morning, and is in deep affliction, at the loss of his daughter— We had evening visits in Succession from Mr. Glück and Lieut Thom. I received three Quarterly accounts current, from the 1st: July 1846; to the 31st. March 1847. from my son—bringing up, my Family and household recounts, to the present time, in addition to those which are constantly kept by us here— On my Son’s last account, there is a balance of $139.50 cents, due to him on the 31st. of March last—

I received this day, a Letter for my wife, from Miss M. S. Hughes, daughter of Mr. Christopher Hughes. in answer to enquiries, concerning her Father’s illness. It is dated on Saturday, and mentions that he is now convalescent. A Letter from Samuel. H. Davis, dated Peoria Illinois, containing some particulars, relating to the Presidential Election, of 1801. He says the circumstances are all detailed, in the Winchester Virginia Republican, in 1832. the author of which he thinks is the Revd. William Hill D.D. A Presbyterian Minister, extensively and deservedly, known in that Church. and he thinks, that a line from me, addressed to this Dr. William Hill at Winchester would doubtless receive instant attention— This Mr. Davis, informs me that he is the brother of the Architect, in New York, consulted last year by my Son, upon my project, for building at Mount Wollaston, a Library Fire Proof for the preservation of my Books, and papers, and those of my Father— I received also a singular Letter from A. S. Todd, dated at Wheeling the 28th. of April last, enquiring, with some degree of formality, my opinion, with regard to the comparitive healthiness, or unhealthiness, of Air, heated by Furnaces, in the Cellar, or basement, of a house, over that heated, by common Fire places— He alleges, that he is building a large and expensive house, at Wheeling, and that his enquiries, are instigated, by the diversities of opinion, which he finds among his friends, on this subject— I took a ride and walk before dinner. Mr. Thom was here this evening, and brought us a sample of Mexican Chapparal— We finished reading of Walpole’s Memoirs, of the first ten years, of the reign of George III— They are not very interesting, as they close, precisely at the time, when the contest between Great Britain and her North American Colonies, become of transcendent importance, to the History of this Country— They relate almost entirely, to the personal intrigues, of the Earl of Chatham the Earl of Bute, the Bedford, and Grenville families, Duke of Grafton, and Marquis of Rockingham. A period of darkness, with which, the only rays of light that pierced the gloom radiate from the mind of Edmund Burke—

I answered the Letter from Samuel H. Davis of Peoria Illinois relating to the Presidential Election of 1801. and wrote also to my Son acknowledging the receipt of his three Quarterly accounts, from the first of July 1846, to the thirty-first of March 1847— I took no other exercise than a ride in the Carriage, towards Evening—

I rode to the Capitol, intending to return to the Library the four Volumes of Walpole’s Memoirs of George III. but the Library was not open— I left the books therefore, in the care of Mr. Buck one of the Clerks, in the Office of the Clerk of the House of Representatives, B. B. French— Mr. French, has risen to the Office of Clerk of the House, after being several years, a subordinate Officer, in it— He is a Democrat, but an excellent Officer— Mr. Buck is one of the subalterns, introduced by McNulty and also very attentive to his duty, and very obliging— Miss Mary Cutts dined with us—

I received a Letter from William Ellis Dedham, Massachusetts, dated the 8th. May, acknowledging the receipt of the Pension Certificate, in favor of the heirs of Relief Dunbar, highly acceptable, as it came quite unexpectedly—after a long and persevering pursuit the final success of which, was owing to his indefatigable perseverance— I rode to the Capitol and found the Volumes of Walpole’s Memoirs were returned to the Library, from which I took out, the five Volumes of Crocker’s edition of Boswell’s Life of Samuel Johnson— During the recess of Congress the Library is open only three days in the week Tuesday’s, Thursday’s and Saturday’s, but the Librarian Mr. Mehan told me that they were in attendance there every day, except on Sundays. I received this day a notification from E. Y. Pope, Secretary of a Prudential Committee, dated South Braintree May 7th. 1847—in the following terms—  At our Society meeting you were chosen, one of the Board of Visitors, for the Horace, Institute, and an examination, of the Students of the Horace Institute will take place, on May 11th. at 1 oclock P.M. and you are respectfully invited to attend, as one, of the Board of Visitors— The singular part, of this matter is, that I know not what the Horace Institute is, and can only conjecture that it is an incorporated School or Academy, in the Town of Braintree— The time of the Meeting being past, before I received this notification, it seems useless for me to answer it.

Mr. White of Philadelphia son of the late Bishop White, paid me a morning visit— I rode this morning to the Navy Yard, stopping at Miss Casey’s lodgings, to return some English Newspapers which she had lent me— I took a short walk in the afternoon, but finding it from day to day, more difficult to walk, fear that I must henceforth, confine all my bodily exercise, to riding in a carriage. I answered the Letter of Mr. Ellis of Dedham— We commenced in the evening, reading the Life of Johnson.

I received from Moses McClean, late member of Congress from the fifteenth Congressional District of Pennsylvania, a card, advertising himself as Attorney at Law, Gettysburg Pennsylvania, and announcing that having withdrawn from Political life, he will devote his attention hereafter exclusively to the practise of his profession and that all Claims Sent to him for collection, will receive prompt attention. The Card concludes with references to sundry well known Political men, of New York, Philadelphia and Baltimore— I received also a Letter from A. S. Todd, of Wheeling asking my opinion, with regard to the healthiness of heating house by Furnaces— I went with Major Graham, to the Office of the Commissioner for Drawing the Boundary Line between the British Possessions, and the United States. at the North-east, conformably to the Ashburton Treaty I examined several of the maps, executed under this Commission and agreed with Major Graham, to examine them further, in the course of next week— Albert Smith of Maine, is the Commissioner on the Part of the United States, and Colonel Estcourt, is the principal agent on the part of Great Britain. We took a ride this afternoon— Captain Casey spent the evening with us—

At the Unitarian Church heard Mr. Bellows, preach from 1. Corinthians 2.9. “Eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither hath entered into the heart of man, the things which God hath prepared for them that love him.” and at St Johns Church in the afternoon, two other Clergymen were in the Pulpit with Mr. Pyne. Mr. Lyle from New York, read the Service, from the Sunday after Ascension day, and a Mr. Sneed preached, from, John 5, and the first part of the 39th. verse, Search the Scriptures— Evening visits from Miss Mary E. E. Cutts, and Lieut. George Thom—

At twelve oclock, I went with Major Graham to the Office of the Commissioners, for settling the Boundary between Great Britain and the United States, according to the Ashburton Treaty— I inspected about sixty sheets, of the map, upon which they had drawn, the line of partition and which has been executed with great precision—

I received from Dr. Thomas Miller a written notification, that at one oclock P.M. tomorrow the Surveyor of the City, at his request would run and ascertain the lines, between our adjoining property, that is to say the dividing Lots in Number 16, and Number 17. in Square No 253, in the City of Washington.

at one oclock P.M. I met Dr. Thomas Miller and the City Surveyor Randolph Coyle, on the spot, of the division Line, between the Lots 16, and 17. in Square No 253, in the City of Washington. The City Surveyor, had already, surveyed and marked out, the division line of which he had given, a plat to Dr. Miller, by which was certified, that my brick stable erected in the year 1821, encroaches, fourteen inches, on the Lot, Number 17. now belonging to Dr. Miller; but which belonged, when my Stable was erected to Dr. William Thornton; and my Stable, was built immediately adjoining to the stable already standing on the Land of Dr. Thornton and placed immediately bordering, upon his boundary— I complained, that this admeasurement had been made by the City Surveyor, for Dr. Miller, without previous notice, given to me— I doubted its legality; and before submitting to it, took time for examining the City, Laws, relating to the powers of the City Surveyor, and the division lines between proprieties of adjoining buildings— Capt Casey and his sister paid us a morning visit—

I examined this morning the Laws of the Corporation of the City of Washington to the end of the 30th. Council June 1833. with an appendix, containing Laws of the United States relating to the City, by Andrew Rathbun— In page 209 of this Book, I found an Act authorizing the appointment of a Surveyor of the City of Washington and establishing a Surveyors Office therein and in page 384, of the same Volume an Act authorizing the proprietors, of Squares and Lots in the City of Washington to have the same subdivided and admitted to Record— These two acts, contain the Laws, by which, the present City Surveyor, and Dr. Miller, have proceeded in the Survey, of the division line, between the Lot 16. belonging to me, and the Lot 17. which belongs partly to Dr. Miller. I called on Mr. Frye, at his Office, and referred him to these two Laws, requesting him to examine, the Plat of the City of Washington, and laid down under the Act of Congress, and recorded, the 4th. of October 1792— Mr. Frye did accordingly, examine the Plat of the City and obtain from the surveyor’s Officer, a certified Copy, of the Square Number 253. He took with him this copy and gave it to me certified by two witnesses himself, and Col Moore— I consulted with Mr. Frye, what I should further do, to secure my own property and I concluded, to have a regular Survey, and Plot, of the two Lots, Number 8. and 16, in Square 253, made by the City Surveyor and a Plot thereof, duly authenticated to ascertain, the Bounds of my own property—and so far as relates, to the encroachment, of my brick Stable, upon the lot Number 17. to abide by the Law, as specially prescribed, in the act, in page 384, of Rothwell’s, edition of the Laws of the Corporation of the City in the fourth section of which it is especially provided for— We took a ride this afternoon, and had evening visits, first from Mr. & Mrs. Robert Greenhow, and afterwards from Mrs. Madison and Miss Payne—

A nearly sleepless, and very uncomfortable night— My Granddaughter Mary Louisa who has been three days on a visit to Mrs. Turnbull returned home—and my Nephew Lieutenant Joseph Harrod Adams, left us for New York— Mr. Frye, was here this morng. and has left with me, an authenticated copy of Square Number 253, as laid down, by the Commissioners of the City and recorded on the 4th. of October 1792. In the agreement between the Commissioners and David Burns, the original Proprietor of this Square. the Lot Number, 8, was assigned, to the Public and the Lot Number 16. would remain to the said David Burns— Mr. Frye will apply to the City Surveyor, for a new Survey of the Lots number 8. and 16. I had some conversation last evening, with Mr. Greenhow, concerning, the expedition of St Dennis, to Mexico, in 1715, and he sent me today, an Article published by him, in the New Orleans Commercial Review of October 1846, and of the New York Evening Post of November 13th.: of the same year with some additional Manuscript notes, all of which are parts, of an unpublished History of Florida, Louisiana, and Texas, by him. In this Article, there is much information, respecting the controvert title to Texas, between France and Spain from its origin—

Mr. Frye, called and left with me, an exact authenticated copy by the City Surveyor Randolph Coyle of a record of Square No 253. on North F. and G. Streets. of the original Plan of the City of Washington made and certified by the Commissioners, on the 4th. day of October 1792— He also wrote me this day a note, stating that Colonel William Brent the Clerk of the Circuit Court, had promised him yesterday, copies of the Deeds, from David Burns, of Lots No 8 and 16 square No two-hundred and fifty three and that the Surveyor of the City had promised to re-survey the Plot, of Lots No 8 and 16, next Tuesday— I received another Note from Mr. Frye, delivered to me by Alexander Borland whom he recommends, as a Carpenter to contract, for repairing the Stable— I visited the Observatory, and saw the West Transit Instruments, the Prime Vertical Instrument, theCircle, the Meridian Circle and the Equatorial— There is another Instrument, called the Refraction Circle ordered, to be made by Ertel at Munich but which has not yet arrived. In the Appendix to the Volume of Astronomical Observations presented me by Lieut M. F. Maury, there is at page 14, a List, of fifteen Officers besides himself attached to the Office. for all its duties of observation and computationone of these is Mr. Sears. C. Walker—between whom and the Superintendent Maury, there appears to be some misunderstanding— In the National Intelligencer of yesterday there was an Article, from Mr. Maury, dated from the Observatory though not signed and an Article this morng signed by Mr. Walker concerning which I spoke to Mr. Maury, with regret as indicating some dissension between them— Mr. Walker complains that he was the person who made the discovery that Lalande the French Astronomer had actually observed in March 1795. as a fixed Star, the recently discovered Planet Neptune—and that Mr. Maury in announcing this fact, had not specially named him Walker, as the person who had first ascertained and announced this fact. Mr. Maury, disclaims any intention of injustice, to Mr. Walker, whose seems to me unreasonable; But the discovery of this New Planet Neptune has led to wonderful excitement among the Astronomers of Europe, and of America, pleasingly indicative of the intense interest, taken in the pursuit of Astronomical Science

At the Unitarian Church this morning where I attended with Elizabeth. C. Adams, Mr. Bellows, preached from Matthew 5.44. “But I say unto you, love your enemies, bless them that curse you, do good to them that hate you, and pray for them that despitefully use you, and persecute you.” In the afternoon, at St John’s Church, Mr. . . . read the evening Service for Whitsunday and preached from 1. Corinthians, 15–20— “But now is Christ risen from the dead and become the first fruits, of them that slept”— A discourse, upon the immortality of man, able, and eloquent, but not so forcible, as I should have desired— In the evening, Isaac Hull Adams, and Lieutenant Thom were here—

I received this morning a Letter from Mrs. Catherine, Maria Frances Smith, with an Order, which she had forgotten to sign, to my Son Charles. Francis Adams, Trustee of T. B. Johnsons Will, to pay me on my order, the sum of one hundred and thirty five dollars advanced to her, this day— For which I gave her a check on the Bank of the Metropolis for thirty five dollars, in addition to that for one hundred dollars which I gave her on the 15th. inst— This Order, I enclosed in a Letter to my son which I forwarded to him this day— I took a ride this evening—and at night we had visits, from Mr. & Mrs. Campbell, Mrs. Key, Miss Ringgold, Dr. Ringgold, Isaac Hull Adams and Lieut Thom—

This day at 12 oclock, with my wife, Mrs. John Adams, and her daughter, Mary Louisa, I took the Cars, for Baltimore— We were accompanied, by Margaret Delany, and Albert Putnam, but we were detained, a full hour, by the failure of the train from Baltimore, to reach Washington, in proper time, and when we arrived at Baltimore, the Steamer in which we had proposed to proceed to Philadelphia this evening, was gone, and we took lodgings for the day at Barnum’s Hotel— In the evening, Mrs. Eleanor Goods joined us from Washington— We sent word to Mr. Christopher Hughes, of our arrival at Baltimore, and he called to see us in the evening—

This day at 12 oclock, with my wife, Mrs. John Adams, and her daughter, Mary Louisa, I took the Cars, for Baltimore— We were accompanied, by Margaret Delany, and Albert Putnam, but we were detained, a full hour, by the failure of the train from Baltimore, to reach Washington, in proper time, and when we arrived at Baltimore, the Steamer in which we had proposed to proceed to Philadelphia this evening, was gone, and we took lodgings for the day at Barnum’s Hotel— In the evening, Mrs. Eleanor Goods joined us from Washington— We sent word to Mr. Christopher Hughes, of our arrival at Baltimore, and he called to see us in the evening—

At nine oclock this morning, we took the Train of Cars, for Philadelphia— Mr. Hughes called upon us again before our departure— We arrived at Philadelphia about three oclock P.M. and took lodgings at the Columbia House, in Chesnut Street. opposite to the Union Hotel, heretofore kept by Mr. Jones. an Englishman, which is now transferred to other Proprietors— The Columbia House is kept by Mr. Hartwell— My wife, Mrs. John and her daughter went to visit Miss Mease in the evening— I ventured, rashly, to stroll out, and take a walk, in Chesnut Street— I met successively, Captain Henry of the Navy and a Mr. Townsend, each of whom walked with me—

At nine oclock this morning, we took the Train of Cars, for Philadelphia— Mr. Hughes called upon us again before our departure— We arrived at Philadelphia about three oclock P.M. and took lodgings at the Columbia House, in Chesnut Street. opposite to the Union Hotel, heretofore kept by Mr. Jones. an Englishman, which is now transferred to other Proprietors— The Columbia House is kept by Mr. Hartwell— My wife, Mrs. John and her daughter went to visit Miss Mease in the evening— I ventured, rashly, to stroll out, and take a walk, in Chesnut Street— I met successively, Captain Henry of the Navy and a Mr. Townsend, each of whom walked with me—

We proceeded, in a Steamer from Philadelphia to Bristol, and from thence, by the Railway to New York— We crossed the river, in the Ferry Boat, and took lodgings, at the City Hotel, at three oclock We had visits from Mrs. and Miss Renwick, and Mr. Renwick, and from Alexander. S. Johnson. We confined ourselves to the house, on account of the rain.

We proceeded, in a Steamer from Philadelphia to Bristol, and from thence, by the Railway to New York— We crossed the river, in the Ferry Boat, and took lodgings, at the City Hotel, at three oclock We had visits from Mrs. and Miss Renwick, and Mr. Renwick, and from Alexander. S. Johnson. We confined ourselves to the house, on account of the rain.

Heavy rain all night, and the former part of this day— We had been invited, to attend the Consecration of Calvary Church, of which Mr. Samuel. L. Southard, the son, of my deceased friend of that name—is to be the Rector—but the state of my health prevented me from attending nor did any of us go— We confined ourselves again, except occasional walks in Broadway, where we met General Gaines and his Lady, who had visited us by cards at the Hotel— At four oclock P.M— we left New York, in a Steamer for Hartford in which about eleven at night, we entered Connecticut river at Saybrook, and proceeded up the river till about five oclock in the morning—

We landed at Hartford and breakfasted at the City Hotel, immediately after which, at Seven oclock, we took the Train of Railway Cars, through Springfield and Worcester to Boston—where we arrived, about one oclock— After waiting until quarter past two, took the Cars of the Old Colony Railroad, to Quincy. We met at the Cars, my Son Charles Francis Adams, his daughter, Louisa Catherine and his son Charles. Francis. At a quarter before three, we landed at the Depot, and I walked, to my own residence. We found my Son and his family, God be praised, in good health, and he with his wife, spent the evening with us. In the Cars at Springfield, we met William, C. Johnson, who was going on, to meet his sister Sarah, who is on a visit to her friends, in Boston and Quincy, and who was to return with him to Utica— Mr. & Mrs. Kirk have left the house, and their connexion with us, and in their place, are a young man and his wife by the name of Hutchinson—

We landed at Hartford and breakfasted at the City Hotel, immediately after which, at Seven oclock, we took the Train of Railway Cars, through Springfield and Worcester to Boston—where we arrived, about one oclock— After waiting until quarter past two, took the Cars of the Old Colony Railroad, to Quincy. We met at the Cars, my Son Charles Francis Adams, his daughter, Louisa Catherine and his son Charles. Francis. At a quarter before three, we landed at the Depot, and I walked, to my own residence. We found my Son and his family, God be praised, in good health, and he with his wife, spent the evening with us. In the Cars at Springfield, we met William, C. Johnson, who was going on, to meet his sister Sarah, who is on a visit to her friends, in Boston and Quincy, and who was to return with him to Utica— Mr. & Mrs. Kirk have left the house, and their connexion with us, and in their place, are a young man and his wife by the name of Hutchinson—

I had born the Journey from Washington rather better than I had expected, but had a very restless and agitated night, which was quieted only by a dose of Paregoric, taken after midnight. Yet I found myself this morning, somewhat restored, to tranquility, and attended Public Worship, at the Stone Temple, morning and afternoon— It was the Communion day, at which, much to my satisfaction, I participated in the ceremony— Mr. Lunt preached, in the morning, from Matthew 12.35, “A good man, out of the good treasure of the heart, bringeth forth good things”—and in the afternoon, from Acts, 4.12. [“]neither is there Salvation, in any other, for there is none other name, under Heaven, given among Men, whereby we must be saved.” William. C. Johnson, came out this day, with his sister Sarah, and dined with us— They went in to Boston again, and Mary Louisa, went with them, to hear the Oratorio, of Moses in Egypt, performed by a company of Italian musicians—

I had a more comfortable night, than the preceeding one, and hope it has restored me, to a state not more disordered, than I was before leaving Washington— I had a visit from the late President Quincy, who proposes, to come with his family, from Boston, to reside at his Seat in Quincy, during the Summer months, tomorrow— I answered the Letter of Mr. C. S. Daveis, of Portland Maine, proposing, as Chairman of a Committee, of the Massachusetts Cincinnati Society, to come and present to me an invitation, to attend their Anniversary Celebration on the next fourth of July, which invitation, I am from the state of my health, compelled to decline— Before dinner I walked up to my Son’s House, and met there his son John Quincy, with three of his companions, one a son of Mr. Emmons, and two sons of Dr. John. G. Palfrey, just returned from the Latin School at Boston— In the afternoon, towards Sunset, I took a ride, with my daughters, Mrs. John and Mrs. Charles Adams—

My Granddaughter Mary Louisa, went into Boston this morning, and returned before dinner, with Sarah. Adams. Johnson, of Utica, the Granddaughter of my brother Charles—who comes to stay for a short time with us— I answered, the Letter of David. D. Field—Secretary of the Committee of Arrangements for a public dinner, to be given to Henry Wheaton, at New-York, on the 10th. of this month— Mr Wheaton has just returned, from a series of Diplomatic missions, in Europe, to which he was first appointed by me, more than twenty years ago, and in which he has distinguished himself, by the publication of several important works— I am compelled in this case also, to decline the invitation to partake of this festivity— I answered also, a Letter, from Judge William Jay, of Bedford, New York, who enclosed to me, copies, of two anonymous Letters, written from Amsterdam in January and May 1782. to Dr. Franklin against my Father; which proved perfectly harmless to him but had the singular effect, of producing, a bitter and violent controversy between Henry Laurens, and Edmund Jennings, who published counter pamphlets, but in which controversy, my Father took no part— Jennings, was a most intimate friend and correspondent of my Father’s during several years of the War, but Mr. Laurens, I never knew why, suspected, that he was the author, of these anonymous Letters— They excited, great sensation at the time, which continued for several years— The Author, was some obscure, and low-lived English Spy, but I never knew, nor did my Father I believe, who he was— Judge Jay, seems not aware, that I was acquainted with these papers, though they had been well known to me, from very shortly after their first composition— I rode with my two daughters in the afternoon, and had as visitors, a man from Pittsburgh calling his name McElroy, who complained, that he had been sent, by his relations to an Insane Hospital at Brattleborough Vermont, from which he was now, returning to Pittsburgh; and from a person belonging to Boston, named, Farnham. who appeared to have no other motive to see me, than curiosity. The ladies went to a party at Mr. Lunts, where they had an Exhibition of Tableaux—

I had again, a quiet and comfortable night’s rest, and all this day, was in that state of health, which I have had upon an average, since the close of the Session of Congress— That I shall ever be better, I have scarce any reason to expect, how long this state will continue, I must leave to the disposal of events— It disqualifies me for all business, and I can write, any thing more than my name, only, with the aid of my Granddaughter, or her mother— My son’s wife, kindly offered me, the same favor, and my own wife, does the same— It can hardly be called life, but tis the destiny ordained for me, and at which. I ought not to repine— I passed a quiet day. and with the help of Mary Louisa, resumed my Diary, from the day of our leaving Washington— I walked before dinner, to my Son’s House on the hill, but he and his wife, were both in Boston, and Mrs. John Adams, who returned to dinner— In the afternoon towards sunset, I rode to Milton, returning by Braintree, and my Son, with his son John, passed the evening here— The Letters to Judge Jay, and to D. D. Field were dispatched, and this evening, the keys of our Trunks, which had been left behind at Washington, and for which my wife had written were received by the mail—

I had morning visits from Mr. Jonathan Baxter, together with Mr. Shepley, a Clergyman, from the State of Maine, also from a black man by the name of Moses Saylor, who came for two purposes, to solicit contributions, first to make up a sum, of many hundred dollars, to redeem from Slavery, his brother and his family, and secondly, to pay the debts. of a Church for people of color, in the State of Maryland. I declined both, and gave him a dollar for himself, as I understood him, he had been, a slave of Francis Thomas. sometime a Member of Congress, and afterwards Governor of Maryland— His brother and family also belonged to Thomas—but he having failed in his pecuniary concerns they had been sold as part of his property, to pay his debts— The sum required to purchase their freedom I think he said was $750—of which he had collected so much as left about four hundred dollars still to be contributed— Thomas, was distinguished as an able member of Congress, but has been much more so; for controversies, with his wife, and several of her relations. My Granddaughter Mary Louisa, and Sarah Johnson, went upon a party to Squantum, with Isaac Hull, Joseph Harrod, Elizabeth. C. Adams, and Mrs. Stebbins, where they dined, and spent the evening at Elizabeth. C. Adams house— I walked before dinner, to my Son’s house, and rode towards evening, with my wife, and Louisa. C. Smith— After our return, my wife was, quite ill, and took to her bed— I was myself not a little indisposed—

I had a more quiet night, than I expected— I have been reading a Book, called the Life of Emanuel Swedenborg. given me, on the 4th. July 1845, by Mr. Hobart of Abington, in which Town, there is a Swedenborgian or New Jerusalem Church— I have made fruitless exertions to understand the character of this man, and of his pretended Revelations, without success— He pretended to have personal and frequent conversations, with God himself, with Angels, with spirits Good and bad, and with persons deceased— He says in the Letter, to a Rev Dr. Hartly an Englishman, after giving some account of his early life “But I regard all that I have mentioned, as matters of respectively little moment, for what far exceeds them, I have been called, to a Holy Office, by the Lord himself, who most graciously manifested himself in person to me his Servant in the year 1745. when he opened my sight to the view of the Spiritual world and granted me, the privilege of conversing, with spirits and Angels, which I enjoy to this day— From that time, I began to print and publish, various.[”]
The storm deprived me of my usual daily exercise— My Son with his two Sons Charles, and Henry dined with us—

8— VII.  The Storm subsided without a clearing off— The Reverend R. C. Waterston Pastor of the Church of the Saviour Bedford Street Boston, who married a daughter of Josiah Quincy preached by exchange with Mr. Lunt— In the morning from John 18.38. “What is truth”— And in the afternoon from Ezekiel 8.5. “Then said he unto me, Son of man, lift up thine eyes now the way towards the north— So I lifted up mine eyes the way towards the north, and, behold, northward, at the gate of the altar, this image of jealousy in the entry”— It was from the wonderful vision of Ezekiel, of which, the preacher gave a somewhat detailed exposition, quoting the Lines from Miltons Paradise Lost—  Mr. Waterston drew from the whole story a solemn and edifying lesson of morality— I invited him to dine with us, but he considered himself engaged at Mr. Quincys— I walked to Meeting in the morning, but rode the remainder of the way— My Son was here in the evening, but his wife was retained at home by the weather the copious rain coming on again this eveg.

From the long continued dampness of the atmosphere, or from my own imprudence in my diet, I had a very restless and almost sleepless night. I took advantage of an interval during which the rain held up for a short walk—

10— VI  The weather cleared off and the summer returned— I had an indifferent night, sleepless and disquieted. I took a very short walk in the morning, and a ride to Mr. Bents Biscuit Bakery to Milton in the Evening— My Granddaughter was much indisposed this day. In the evening Elizabeth. C. Adams and Isaac Hull, were here with Edward Frothingham.

11. VI.  A warm and trying Summer day. After a restless and sleepless night, I was deprived of my walk and the portion of time which I could devote to any occupation, was spent in reading newspapers, Articles in Littell’s Living Age, and Beloes’ Herodotus. It serves the hour but leaves no impression I have got through with Clio—Euturpe, and Thalia, and half Melpomene— But this most ancient of Profane Historians seems rather a collector of Anecdotes than merely an Historian— A very small portion of the Anecdotes appear to have any foundation in fact, and they are all discredited by the perpetual occurence of the marvellous— There is also an inextricable confusion of names and the same persons, are mentioned by different names in Herodotus, Diodorus Seculus, Justin the Abbreviator of Trogus Pompeius whose work has perished, and the scriptures of the Old Testament. Chronology prior to the age of Alexander of Macedon is an inextricable chaos— The writings of David, of Solomon, and of Homer about twelve hundred years before Christ, stand unaccountable monuments of Literature in a very high degree of improvement, with a subsequent period of at least seven hundred years, of total barbarism. The Psalms of David, the Proverbs of Solomon, and the Illyad and Oddissy of Homer are phenomena in the History of literature hitherto unexplained. and in all probability so to remain notwithstanding the recent discovery of the secret of Hierogliphical writing. Had visits from Mr. Loring of Hingham accompanied by Mr. Richard Smith of Philadelphia his wife and daughter. Mr. Smith recollects an acquaintance with us in 1811, when we resided at Saint Petersburgh in Russia— My Son gave me a check for one-hundred dollars upon the Merchants Bank at Boston. At half past eleven oclock this evening, Mrs. Hutchinson, wife of the man who lives with us as a farmer, was delivered of a Son—

12. VI.  Another sleepless night; succeeded by another fair, day, of very oppressive Summer heat. My Wife and Mrs. John Adams went with the carriage me into Boston— They, returned home to dinner— We rode this evening round Mt Wollaston and were much tormented by musquitos. There was a Convention of Teachers of the Primary School, held this day at the Stone Meeting House— While I was out riding a Committee from the Convention, called and told my wife that they wished to pay me a visit tomorrow in a body. For which she appointed ten oclock in the morning— The Reverend Dr. John Codman of Dorchester and his wife called also while I was out. In the Evening my Son passed an hour with us, but his wife was not with him.

13. VI.  I had a second almost totally sleepless night, and consequent weakness throughout the day. At nine this morning I rode to the Stone Bank, and deposited there a Check in the Merchants Bank Boston for one hundred dollars, given me by my Son— I drew also at the same time two Checks, drawn by myself on the Stone Bank one of one hundred dollars, in favor of Mrs. Mary. C. Adams, for our household expenses, and one of thirty dollars, in my own favor for the same purpose—both of which I received in small Bills. The hundred dollars I gave to Mary for the current daily expenses— At ten oclock the Teachers male and Female, of the Convention paid me their visit. and their presiding Officer made me a short Address, which I answered I know not how— One of them a Mr. Nathaniel Wolcott made inquiries respecting his Grandfather Oliver Wolcott— Another brought me a Letter from the Reverend Calvin Durfee, of South Dedham, and an Album in which he requested me to write some Lines. His name was Lemuel Shattock— A Mr. Bliss came afterwards alone—and I was requested to write out my Answer to the Address which had been made to me by them. I found this impossible and was only able to write a few Lines in the Album. Towards Evening I rode with my Wife and Mrs. John Adams to Braintree returning by the way of Milton— We had for evening visitors, Mr. Glück, Mr. Williams, Edward Frothingham, Isaac Hull, and John Quincy. Mrs. Charles, my Son, and his son John Quincy were also here— At the close of the day I found myself much exhausted— This was the Birthday, of my Sons daughter Louisa Catherine, who is sixteen years old— She is now on a visit to Mrs. Sedgwick at Lenox.

14— V.  I had fortunately a night of quiet sleep but found myself not so much after it as I had expected— Little if anything recruited in my strength and not at all in my Spirits. Mr. Shattock came for Mr. Durfee’s Album, in which I had written some lines and returned the Books to him without finishing them—nor had I been able to write out, my answer to the Address and very probably shall not be. Mr. Horace Mann, the School Commissioner delivered last evening an Address to the Convention in the Town Hall which I was invited to attend, but could not— The weather is still at Summer heat— The Brothers John Quincy and Joseph. H. Adams. were here— Joseph returned yesterday afternoon from a fortnight’s excursion, to Canada, Saratoga, and Utica. I received a Card of invitation from the President of Harvard University Edward Everett in behalf of the Corporation to the Exhibition and dinner in the Hall on Commencement Day the 25th. of this month— I received also a Letter from Robert Malone, dated Noxuba County Mississippi Somerville August 2d. making inquiries concerning Andrew Walker who in his last Will, claims to have served as an Officer in the Pennsylvania Line through the War, and thereby to have become a member of the Cincinnati in the State of Pennsylvania. And he bequeaths, all his interest in the Funds of the said Cincinnati to his daughter Charlotte Walker to her Heirs and Assigns forever— Mr. Malone states that he had written to Philadelphia for the necessary information to enable the Executor of Andrew Walker to get the Funds if any, but was referred to me as more able to give the information than any other person. It is strange that I know not to whom excepting Joseph. B. Bird, to whom I could apply, to obtain this information— I received also a Pamphlet entitled the Daguerreotype a magazine of Foreign Literature and Science selected chiefly from the Periodical Publications of England France and Germany. 1847. Volume one, number one—Boston. Published by J. M. Whitemore—114. Washington Street, and addressed to me by the Authors. I rode in the Evening with my wife, Miss Louisa C. Smith and my Granddaughter Mary Louisa round Braintree—

15.  Mr. Lunt preached this morning from Ephesians 2.12. Without God in the World and this afternoon from Matthew 20.26–27. Whosoever will be great among you let him be your minister. 27. And whosoever will be Chief among you, let him be your servant— In the Discourse of the morning Mr. Lunt remarked, that there were, among Men a much greater number who live without God in the World, than was generally believed. That professed atheists were not very common; but that every person who manifested their disbelief, of the existence of a Supreme Being, to whom they were responsible for their lives upon Earth, must be held to live without God in the World— The Discourse of the Afternoon, was upon a more familiar Doctrine of Religious Morals. I walked to and from Church in the morning but rode in the afternoon. The weather is cool, and threatens and easterly storm— My Son was here in the Evening, with his Son Charles.

16. VI.  The weather continues cool, almost cold, so that I had a fire made this morning in my Bed chamber. I had a morning visit, from Mr. Edmund Chadwick a Clergyman from Bangor in the State of Maine; with whom I had, much conversation, particularly upon my translation of the Psalms. He requested of me an Autograph which I gave him— Mrs. Charles Adams went to Boston and was not here this day— We had a visit from Mr. Nathaniel Curtis of Roxbury and his wife— They came out to see Mr. Thomas Boylston who is living for the Summer at Board at French’s Tavern. As they did last Summer, but have not called upon us either then nor now— The eldest Son named Ward Nicholas, is residing with his Father, John Boylston, and his Family at the Princeton Estate— He has been educated as a Phycian and is called the Dr. but does not practise, and neither the Father or either of the sons follow any occupation whatever— They live upon the income left them by the Will of Mr. Ward Nicholas Boylston, and in nowise as a harmonious family— I took an Evening ride with my wife, and Mrs. John Adams— My Grandaughter Mary Louisa took an afternoon ride on horseback— My Son was here in the Evening and the day closed with a cool evening—

17— VI.  I had a tolerable quiet night, but a somewhat uneasy morning. I had a fire again in my Bed chamber, but the morning soon cleared away to the temperature of Summer— I walked round the Railway Square, before noon— I took a ride about the time of Sunset with my Wife, and Mrs. Charles, and Louisa. C. Smith, to Braintree returning by the road through the Quarries. My Son and his wife were here in the Evening. Albert Putnam who has lived with us some time as Coachman gave notice to my Son, that he is about to leave us, and to go into business—

18. VI.  A half nights rest, and a half days walk before dinner. Mrs. Charles, and Elizabeth, went to a Tea Party at Mrs. Seaver’s in Dorchester. Mrs. John Adams, was quite ill, confined to her room. We had as evening visitors Mr. Josiah Quincy and his son in Law Mr. Waterston— Also Mr. Beale and his two daughters— My Son was also here— The Cambria a Steamer of the Cunard Line, arrived this day, after a passage of fourteen days, from Liverpool— The Missouri a vessel of the French Line of Steamers, recently put into operation the second of the line, has been so mismanaged that instead of making her destined Port of of New York, seems to have missed her way, and brought in by the aid of other vessels to Halifax. There is another Line, called the American Line plying between New York and Bremen. Both these Lines are rivals to the Cunard Line, the only one that has hitherto been successful—

19. VI.  The last night, the change of Season, from the Summer to the Autumnal atmosphere took place, and with a brisk north west wind, I was enabled to take a morning walk of a mile and a half— I rode this Evening with Mrs. Charles Adams, Louisa C. Smith, and my Granddaughter Mary Louisa. Mrs. Charles Adams was here in the Evening.

20— VI.  I dined at my Sons with Mr. Alexander Vattemare, the twofold personage, as a Stage Player, and Ventriloquist, and as the projector, of Exchanges of Books, who was here, in the years 1840. and 41. and then returned to France, and has now made his second visit to this Country, bringing with him, it is said, almost 12000. volumes in Exchange, for other books to be collected from the Public Libraries of the scientific Institutions of the several States, and the Libraries of the State Legislatures— Just as we were about to sit down to Table, Mr. Filmore of Buffalo in the State of New York, came to pay me a visit and dined with us. Mr. Charles Brooks of Boston came also while we were at dinner. Mr. Vattemare appears to have lost none of his zeal and enthusiasm for his project and system of exchanging Books. He professes however, to have abdicated his second character of Ventriloquist and stage Player— He is now, no longer Mr. Alexander but simply Mr. Vattemare— He and Mr. Filmore, returned to Boston by the Railroad Cars and both propose to leave the City tomorrow— I rode with Mrs. Charles Adams to Milton leaving Mr. George. T. Bigelow with my Son—

21— VI.  I had an indifferent nights rest, but took a walk this morning round the long Square. The past midshipman John Quincy, came to take leave, being ordered to Norfolk in Virginia, and the Lieut his brother has orders to repair to Charlestown— I rode after dinner with my Wife, Louisa. C. Smith and my Granddaughter Mary Louisa, round Milton Hill— Miss Mary E. E. Cutts, has been some time, at Mr Hubbards a member of Congress at Middletown Connecticut, and has promised to make us a visit, and was expected to arrive last evening— My Grandaughter went to Boston to meet her, but she did not come—

22— VI.  I had a restless and almost sleepless night. Mr. Amos Smith Colleague of Dr. Francis Parkman, as Minister of the new North Church Hanover Street Boston preached by Exchange with Mr. Lunt— morning text was from Matthew 10,31. “Ye are of more value than many Sparrows.” and the object of the Discourse was, to expatiate upon the value of man considered in the light of appreciath property a subject somewhat singular, and novel in its character Mr. Smith dined with us and his afternoon Discourse was from Hebrews 12.2. “Looking unto Jesus, the author and finisher of our faith.” Returning from Meeting in the afternoon, in the evening I found Mr. De Grand here from Boston. who took Tea with us, and remained part of the Evening here— My Son and his wife, Elizabeth C. Adams, and her brothers Joseph, and Hull, with Mr. Glück, were also here as Evening visitors. I visited this morning the Office Room, in the Farm house, where the Library, given by my Father, to the Town of Quincy is still deposited though to be soon transferred to the new Town House and I borrowed, several Volumes, of the Work by Dupuis, entitled, Origine de tous Les Cultes, ou Religion Universelle, par Dupuis Citoyen François, published at Paris, L’An III. De La République, Une et Indivisible. with the motto Liberté, Égalité, Fraternité— not one person in ten thousand, in France at this day, knows, that this was in the year 1795, when among the Revolutions of the time, when the Christian Calendar had been abolished by the National Convention of France, and the epoque of the French Republic had been substituted in the stead of the Christian era— The Era, of the Republic one and indivisible, was very soon exchanged, for that of the Empire, and the Christian Era was restored in 1804, ten years before the restoration of the monarchy— There are some written notes, by my Father, to the Preface and first pages of Dupuis. I have taken the Book out with the purpose of reading it through.

23— VI.  I had a more quiet night than those of several preceding days— I was able to walk, round the short Square before dinner. Our Coachman Albert Putnam, took leave of me this day and departed, Another has come to take his place his name is Wheeler, and we rode this Evening to Braintree returning by the way of Bents Point— Mrs. Charles Adams went this morning to Boston but neither she nor her husband were here this Evening— Their Son John Quincy came in their stead— Her daughter Louisa was expected and returned from her visit to Lenox— Miss Cutts was also expected but did not come.

24—  This was the day of the monthly meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society—but I did not attend it, having had a very indifferent nights rest— I had a professional visit from Dr. Woodward who modified some of his prescriptions— I walked round the long Square in a warm Summer day, suffering from cold. I had a visit also from Mrs. Fairfield who brought a Life of her Son the Poet, for whose works she was soliciting subscriptions as long as he lived, and now derives her subsistence, by peddling about the world his life. In the afternoon I rode with my wife, Mrs. John and Mrs. Charles Adams round Milton returning by the way of the Quarries.

25. VI.  Commencement Day at Cambridge—to which Mrs. John and Mrs. Charles Adams with their two daughters went. The two young Ladies remained at Cambridge at the Presidents House Mr. Everetts, the mothers returned home this Evening about nine oclock— I walked up to my sons House after dinner, and was sitting with him, when I was called home, by a visit from Mr. Degrand, accompanied by two young Ladies one of whom he introduced by the name of Miss Nash of Boston, the other by a name which I do not recollect belonging to Virginia, and visiting Boston as a stranger. They took tea with us, and remained until nearly nine oclock in the Evening—

26—  This was the day after Commencement at Cambridge there celebrated by the annual Exhibition of the Boylston Prize Declamations and by the delivery of an Oration before the Phi Beta Kappa Society— Our two young ladies, remained at Cambridge not to hear the Prize Declamations but to hear the Oration of Mr. George. P. Marsh the member of Congress from Vermont, before the Phi Beta Kappa Society. The usual annual performance is of a Poem in addition to the Oration— That however was omitted this year and the Oration itself though an eloquent and learned Discourse appears to have not quite so satisfactory to the audience, as has been for several preceding years—The young ladies returned home this evening. Mr. Ezekiel Bacon of Utica N.Y. paid me a long morning visit, and dined with my sons wife on the Hill— My Son himself attended the Phi Beta Kappa Meeting at Cambridge and returned with my Granddaughters— I took a short walk before dinner—and in the evening I ride with my wife, in which we missed the road so as to cross the Granite Bridge to Dorchester in consequence of which we were compelled to return over the Neponset Bridge— Mrs. Frothingham, came out from Boston, and dined with her sister, as did also Mrs. John Adams. My son and his wife were here this Eveg.

27. VI.  I dined, at my Son’s House, with Mr. Wheaton heretofore a Reporter of Decisions of the Supreme Court of the United States, appointed by me in the year 1827 Chargé D’Affairs of the United States at the Court of Denmark, subsequently appointed I believe by Mr. Van Buren Minister Plenipotentiary of the Court of Russia at which Court he has been for the last ten years residing as Minister; and has recently returned with his family, to his own Country. He resides at Providence in the State of Rhode Island and is now on a visit to Boston. He came out, with my Son in the Railway Cars at a quarter before three and returned in the Evening Cars, which went from here quarter after six. I took a ride with my Wife and Mrs. John Adams to Braintree. There was a visitor who came while I was at my son’s house, and said he would come again tomorrow— My own condition differs not materially from day to day— I have received a Letter from Wm. Slade, dated at Saratoga Springs the 23d. of this month, with a Circular to the friends of popular Education in the United States, containing the Constitution of the Board of National Popular Education of which Mr. Slade is a general Agent, and for which he request my aid and cooperation To this Letter, I must return an elaborate answer which I commenced this day, but which I know not whether I shall ever be able to finish—

28. VI.  Miss Cutts arrived last evening from Mr. Hubbard’s Connecticut. I walked round the long square, and in the afternoon rode with my Wife and Mrs. Charles Adams, and Miss Cutts over Milton Hill, where we stopped at the Summer residence of the Revd. Mr. Lothrop Pastor of the Brattle street Church and left an invitation to him from my Son to dine with him next Monday in company with a Class-mate of them both, now a visitor here from Louisiana. Isaac Hull, and Joseph Harrod, were here in the Evening— There were two persons who called on me this day one named Joyce, from Bangor in the state of Maine and the other Spencer Atherton who was a mendicant, for his brother, a mechanic who has suffered much from ill health and other misfortunes—

29. VI—  Almost every member of the family was this day complaining of indisposition, from which I almost alone was exempt. The Reverend Mr. Augustus Whitney settled as Pastor of a Congregational Church at Brighton and second son of the Revd. Peter Whitney, Minister of the Congregational Church at Quincy preached in exchange with Mr. Lunt. His morning text, was Psalm 37.37. “Mark the perfect Man, and behold the upright for the end of that man is peace.” And his Afternoon text was from Habackuk 2.3. [“]Though it tarry wait for it” This is only part of the whole of which is [“]for the vision is yet for an appointed time, but at the end it shall speak and not lie though it tarry wait for it, because it will surely come, it will not tarry”— The whole verse is very striking and the portion of it selected by Mr. Whitney is a theme of great significance, well expounded—which I thought it was by Mr. Whitney— He dined with us, though I was obliged to leave him immediately after dinner, for short repose before repairing to the afternoon meeting— We had no evening visitors, and I retired at an early hour

30— VI.  The beautiful Summer weather continues with cool and dewy nights. We have the account of the death of a highly distinguished Citizen a Native of Amherst Massachusetts, but an inhabitant of the State of New York, long a member of Congress from that State and recently its Governor, in expectancy a Candidate for election as President of the United States, and whose decease will probably modify very considerably the canvass for that election— He died at his residenceof apoplexy. I took a ride this afternoon with my wife Mrs. John Adams and Miss Cutts. We had evening visits from President Quincy and the Rev Waterston—

31— VI.  The fine weather continues, and the state of my health during the day depends upon the degree of rest that I get by sleep in the night. This differs from one night to another, and from causes, which I am unable to anticipate or account for. I find it more and more difficult to take morning walks, and have almost given them up. My time is almost exclusively occupied in reading and in addition to the . . . of Herodotus, with whom I have not yet concluded, I have now undertaken to read the Origine de tous les Cultes, ou Religion Universelle par Dupuis Citoyen Francois— I commented upon the first part of the second Volume but I find him, growing so dull as I proceed that I fear I shall not read him through. And so I am commencing on another writer much of the same complexion an English author groping for vestiges of the Natural History of the Creation which my Son, has borrowed for me from the Boston Athenaeum— I rode this afternoon, with Mrs. John and Mrs. Charles Adams, to Braintree returning by the Railway through the Quarries. My Son and his wife were here, and the day closed with a mild Summer Eveg.

1. VI.  My night’s rest was divided into two parts, the first terminating just before daylight and the second after sunrise, and I had strength this morning to walk round the short Railway Square.— I answered the Letter from William Slade, though it will not probably be to his satisfaction— His project is for the improvement of popular Education a very excellent design, but in my apprehension, there is but one improvement, for popular education, desirable for the improvement of man and of his happiness upon Earth, not I fear included, in the operations of Mr. Slade, however embraced in his ultimate purposes. It is not yet undertaken and I fear will not be for many years, though I cannot doubt, that it will be undertaken and accomplished at some future day— I received also a Letter from Mr. Henry Gassett including an Extract of one to him, from Mr. William H. Seward of the State of New York, to whom he had sent a copy of the new Edition of my writings upon the Masonic Controversy— My wife received two small boxes of Honey as a present from Mr. Wm. Ellis of Dedham, for which she returned a Letter of thanks— It is on the part of Mr. Ellis, a testimonial of his thanks for the services I have rendered him in recovering Pensions for several of his friends, and particularly for the heirs of Peter Dunbar— I rode this afternoon with Mrs. John Adams, and Miss Mary Cutts, to Braintree, returning by Dr. Storrs meeting House and the Weymouth Turnpike. Mrs. Charles and her daughter took Tea and spent the Evening here. My wife was not well enough to ride with us this day. I read, Dupuis, upon Universal Religion, and the anonymous, Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation— My Son was here in the Eveg—

2. VI.  Morning visit from Joshua Leavitt, who has just ceased from being the Editor of the Emancipator Newspaper. I walked round the short Square before dinner; and towards Evening rode to Milton with my wife, Mrs. John Adams and Miss Cutts. I continue reading Dupuis Universelle Religion and the Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation— Two works of a totally different character but tending to one result, and both equally unsatisfactory.

3. V  J. Wingate Thornton, Cousin of Miss Cutts visited her here this morning. and this evening Mrs. John Adams and her daughter, My Son and his daughter Louisa Catherine and Miss Cutts, went to Boston to witness the Theatrical performances of Mrs. Bishop an Italian Prima Donna now exhibiting in that City. They returned about Midnight home, much pleased with their entertainment—

4. VI—  In taking my walk round the short Square this morning I met Mr. Lunt who told me Mr. William R. Alger was to be ordained as Minister of the Mount Pleasant Congregational Society in Roxbury next Wednesday at 1/2 past 2. oclock in the afternoon. That the first Congregational Church in Quincy was among the Churches invited to take part in this Ordination and he asked my consent to propose to the Church as a Delegate to attend with him which I gave the answer being conditional in case the state of my health should admit. I rode this afternoon with my wife, Mrs. Charles Adams, to Braintree— Evening visits from Joseph. H. and John Quincy who has just returned from Norfolk. I received a Letter from President Edward Everett, proposing to me as Chairman of the Committee of the Board of Overseers of Harvard University for visiting the Astronomical Observatory to appoint an early day for the visitation; concerning which I must consult Mr. Josiah Quincy and Abbott Lawrence—

5— VI—  We have had a long series of warm and dry weather during which my state of health has been tolerable and promising. Last night my rest was much broken and I find myself very weak this day— Mr. Lunt preached at home in the morning from Nehemiah 6.3. “And I sent messengers unto them saying I am doing a great work so that I cannot come down why should the work cease whilst I leave it and come down to you”— The stress of this Discourse was upon the words “I am doing a great work,” which Mr. Lunt applied to his hearers, who had all he said “a great work” to do— But the Discourse Historical— The great work which Nehemiah was doing was of a character different from that which Christian hearers of the present day are called to perform,— Into the historical portion of the text he did not enter very deeply only mentioning that Nehemiah was Cup Bearer of ArtaxerxesKing of Persia by whose authority Nehemiah was authorized to accomplish the rebuilding of the Temple of Jerusalem. first commanded by Sirus. after the Babylonian captivity— This was a most interesting period of the History of the Tribe of Judah consequent to its extinction as a separate Kingdom from that of the Ten Tribes otherwise called the Samaritans. It would require a deeper insight into the History of the two Kingdoms than was taken by Mr. Lunt. And among other things it would require a development of the rivalship and mutual hatred between the Kingdoms of Judah and of Samaria, to which there is repeated allusion in the new Testament but no full explanation of it given. The Kingdom of Judah was partially restored and the Temple of Jerusalem reconstructed until finally destroyed by the Romans—the Kingdom of Samaria was never restored nor is it known what became of the remnant of the Children of Israel which had separated from the Descendants of Judah— this part of the sacred History is left in great obscurity and there have been Historical inquirers who pretend to discover traces of that people among the Tribes of North American Indians— Mr. Lunts Afternoon Sermon was from Phillippians 4.12. “I know how to abound”—which is only a part of the verse, the whole of which is, “I know both how to be abased, and I know how to abound, everywhere, and in all things, I am instructed, both to be full, and to be hungry, both to abound, and to suffer need.” There was nothing particularly remarkable in this Discourse. I received a Pamphlet entitled Christianity and Slavery. A review of Drs. Fuller and Wayland on domestic Slavery—by William Hague a Baptist Minister in Boston Pastor of a Church in Bedford Street— Drs. Fuller and Wayland are also Baptist Ministers one of Beauford South Carolina the other of Providence Rhode Island where he is President of Brown University— In this controversy Dr. Fuller, sustains the cause of Slavery and Wayland betrays the cause of Christianity—as is honestly shown, by Mr. Hague—

6. VI.  After two sleepless nights I had one tolerably quiet with rain and a change of temperature in the atmosphere from warm to cool and after six days without a visit from either of my Mulatto Barbers, I was finally shaved this afternoon by my Sons man Michael— To this state of dependence I am reduced, from the inability to shave myself and to the want of punctuality in other Shavers. I rode this afternoon with Mrs. Charles Adams Miss Cutts and my Granddaughter, and called at Mr. Josiah Quincys— I agreed with him to propose to the other Members of the Committee of the Overseers of Harvard University for visiting the Observatory at Cambridge—to fix upon Tuesday the 14th. of this month for that visitation, for which purpose I promised to go to Boston tomorrow and confer with Mr. Abbott Lawrence—and any other Member of the Committee that I may find there— The appointment of the day is the duty of the President of the University, but Mr. Everett consulting my particular convenience has referred it to me—a somewhat troublesome task.

7. V.
