I h  I had a tolerable quiet night and slept till daylight— This morning, after breakfast I called upon Mr. Lunt who agreed to take an early dinner with me to morrow and go with me in my carriage to the Mount Pleasant Congregational Church to the Ordination of the Rev Mr. Alger which is to take place at half past two oclock P.M. but the Meeting of the Counsil is to be at half past one, and we are to dine at twelve and to go at half past twelve, so as to reach the place by the time of the meeting of the Counsil— I then went in the Carriage with my wife, Miss Cutts, and Mary Louisa, to Boston the Ladies leaving the Carriage at the Corner of Summer Street— I then went first to the Counting House of Abbott and Amos Lawrence in Milk Street, where I found Mr. Abbott Lawrence but he was going next Monday to New York. from whence he will not return till the end the week, I therefore agreed with him to request President Everett to fix on Tuesday the 21st. of this month at ten oclock in the morning as the time for the Committee of the Board of Overseers of Harvard University to visit the Observatory for which Mr. Lawrence promised to give due notice to the other Members of the Committee with the exception of President Quincy, whom I agreed to notify. The other Members are David Sears, who is at Newport, Theodore Lyman, Robert— T— Paine, J. Ingersoll Bowditch, and Francis Peabody of Salem— Mr. Abbott Lawrence has very recently made a donation of fifty thousand dollars to Harvard University for the establishment of a Professorship of Practical Science, for which I this day offered him my personal hearty thanks, and told him that if I had not given them to him before in writing, they had been in my heart from the first moment I had heard of this more than princely munificence. I next proceeded to my sons Office No 23 Court Street, where I found him, with Mr. Charles Sumner— Mr. Shepherd one of the Editors of the Boston Daily Whig came in with several Newspapers and spoke of some trouble in the Whig Party at New Bedford—which however was not fully explained to me— A more important incident is stated in some of this days newspapers that is that on Monday the 30th. of August a fight occurred at Drummond Town, Accomac County, Virginia between Thomas. H. Bayly, the member of Congress from the Accomac District and Mr. Finney one of the Representatives of the County in the Legislature of the State growing out of the late Division of the Methodist Episcopal Church, in which Bayly, shot Finney in the thigh The excitement is said to be intense—Bayly was imprisoned in the Jail a part of Monday, has been compelled to leave the County, and on Friday the 3d. September took passage in the Boat for Baltimore— The excitement is said to have prevailed to such an extent that on Monday one of the magistrates of the County went on the Bench armed with a pair of Revolving Pistols and a Bowie knife. But what the cause of the excitement was, except late division of the Methodist Episcopal Church, is not told. From my Sons Office I called at Dr. Bigelows House on Summer Street;—but he was not at home— I met the Ladies here, and went to Dr Frothinghams, but Mrs. Frothingham went this day to Medford and the Dr. himself was not at home— After waiting for his return till some time past one oclock we returned to Quincy, to dinner. After which, I took a walk round the short Square and in the Eveg. my son and his Wife, with Louisa Catherine were here in Mr. Beale and his daughter Ann, also paid us an hour’s visit—

8— VI—  A quiet night and Sleep till daylight— at twelve oclock, noon Mr. Lunt took an early dinner with me, immediately after which, we went together in my Carriage to the Church of the Mount Pleasant Congregational Society at Roxbury where we attended the ordination of the Reverend Wm. Alger— We found the Council assembled, and the . . . of the Delegates invited to the ceremony calling over by the Rev John Pierce D.D. Pastor of the Church at Brookline acting as Scribe— The Churches invited were more numerous than usual; and there were in attendance as many as forty Pastors, each with one lay Delegate— When they were all called over Dr. Pierce observed that before proceeding to the ordination it was usual for the person to be ordained to produce some testimonials of his qualifications for the Office of the Ministry, but Mr. Alger observing that he was known to many of the gentlemen in attendance, he had not thought it necessary to obtain any testimonials to his qualifications. No objection however was made to proceeding— Dr. Pierce then observed that it was also usual, for the person about to be Ordained to give some account of his opinions and the Doctrines of his Faith, and he enquired if any person desired this of Mr. Alger. A motion was accordingly made that he should be requested to give such an account. An Amendment was proposed to the Motion to substitute the word required instead of requested. And upon taking the vote the word requested was retained— And upon the vote with the word requested the answers in the affirmative and negative were so nearly equal that the moderator declared he was unable to determine on which side the decision had been— He then proposed that those who were for requesting the candidate, to declare his opinions should show their sense by rising in their seats whereupon twenty two members rose. after which the members against making the request rose and they were nine in number. Whereupon Dr. Pierce declared the majority were in favor of making the request which he accordingly did Mr. Alger then summed up his Faith in the belief of the existence of a God, the immortality of the Soul, and the responsibility of Man to his Maker in a future World. No further inquiries were made and the vote was immediately taken to proceed to the Ordination. They began with an Anthem, followed by an introductory Prayer by the Revd. F. D. Huntington of Boston whose Ordination I attended as Delegate from the Church some three or four years since. In the order of exercises it was said that selections from Scriptures should be read by the Rev Nathl. Hall, but this part was omitted— A Hymn by the Rev Henry Ware Junior was then sung, and a Sermon was preached by the Rev Samuel. K. Lothrop Pastor of the Brattle Street Church in Boston. His text was from 2 Corinthians 2–16. “Who is sufficient for these things”—and his argument was that a minister of the Gospel to be fitted for his Office, should be sufficient for all things— The Sermon was succeeded by the Prayer of Ordination by the Rev Horatio Alger an uncle of the candidate— Then came the Charge, by the Rev Ephraim Peabody, then the right hand of Fellowship by the Rev Edward Everett Hale, then a Hymn by Charles Sprague Esqr. then an Address to the Society by Revd. George Putnam D.D. then a concluding prayer by the Revd. N. G. Thomas then a closing Hymn a Doxology from  then the Benediction by the Pastor himself, according to Custom. The solemnities had commenced at 1/2 past two oclock, it was near six when they closed. The Church was very crowded and the weather oppressively warm. I had been part of the time apprehensive of fainting, but made out to get through and immediately to return home, in the Carriage which took Mr. Lunt home. There had been several strangers here visitors from the State of Michigan and in the evening my Son and his wife were here.

11 VI.  I had been apprehensive that the fatigue of attending the Solemnities of the Ordination at the Mount Pleasant Congregational Society at Roxbury would have been too much for my feeble state of health, and would have been followed by a distressed and unquiet night. But in this I was favourably disappointed as I had a very quiet night succeeded by a comfortable day. Mrs. Charles Adams, with her daughter, Miss Cutts and Mary Louisa went to Boston this morning to return to dinner. President Quincy was here, and I informed him of the agreement I had made with Mr. Abbott Lawrence the day before yesterday to request President Edward Everett to appoint Tuesday the 21st. this month at ten oclock in the morning for a visitation of the Observatory at Cambridge by the Committee of the Board of Overseers of Harvard University—and I agreed to call on President Quincy at his house on that day, and that we will go together to be at Cambridge in the morning at ten oclock. I rode this afternoon with Mrs. John Adams and Miss Mary Cutts round the Quarries. We had Evening visits from Isaac Hull, and John Quincy— I make slow progress in my reading both of Dupuis Universelle Religion and in the anonymous Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation— I find these books very dull. And to enliven the occupation I propose to add the perusal of the Articles Telescope and Glass in Rees Cyclopedia.

10. VI—  Mrs. Mary Catherine Adams birthday. Dr. Woodward was here this morning and I gave him an indifferent account of my condition of favorable improvement of which I have little encouragement to expect. I began reading the Articles Telescope and Glass, and immediately found myself ignorant beyond all conception. Even of the difference between flint glass and crown glass, and equally so, of that between Telescopes constructed upon the principles of Catoptics and those of Dioptics For the time and opportunity to study all this the remainder of my life is not sufficient— The discoveries in practical Astronomy commencing with that of the Planet Uranus have all been dependent upon the improvement of the Instruments used for Astronomical Observations, that is enlarging by Artificial means the power of the Human eye, and if future discoveries, of the mechanism of the Universe all depend upon the extent to which the power of vision in the bodily frame of man may be enlarged. Of all the senses belonging to man it is by the sight alone that he can form conceptions of the structure of the Universe—from the other senses of Hearing, feeling, Smell, and taste, he can receive no assistance to convey intelligence to the mind and it would seem that his sight can be enlarged only by the means of instruments of glass— Until the year 1785—all the researches of the human mind in Astronomy had only discovered its own delusions respecting the Solar system and its own errors in trusting for thousands of years to the movements of the Heavenly bodies as they appear to the naked eye—all totally different to the ostensible Reports of the daily changes of day and night— I took a ride this afternoon with Miss Louisa. C. Smith and Miss Mary Cutts round Milton returning by the Neponset road— My son was here in the Evening—

11— VI  I wrote yesterday to President Edward Everett requesting him to appoint Tuesday 21st. of this month for the visitation of the Observatory by the Committee of the Board of Overseers of Harvard University—and this morning I received a Letter from my niece Susan B. Treadway, from Richmond Virginia of the 7th. inst enclosing an order from the Bank of Virginia upon the Bank of America of New York for one hundred and ten dollars, in part payment of a loan of two hundred dollars which she had made last September— I received also a Letter from W. W. Brown second assistant Postmaster General concerning the Post Office at West Wrentham in this County—which will require an answer. a Letter also from N Sargent Philadelphia of the sixth instt. appraising me that he proposes to be a Candidate for the appointment of Clerk of the House of Representatives of the United States at the approaching Session of Congress but my vote is already promised if called to give it to Mr. B. B. French the Clerk of the last Congress— The storm of rain continuing the whole day prevented my taking my usual ride this afternoon. and we had no company in the evening—

12— VI  The storm of rain continued all night and in showers through the day The Rev Siras. A. Bartol Colleague Pastor with the Rev Dr. Charles Lowell at the West line Street Congregational Church Boston preached by exchange with Mr. Lunt— His morning text was from Romans 1.20. For the invisible things of him from the creation of the World are clearly seen being understood by the things that are made even his eternal power and God head—and Romans 2.15. [“]Which shew the work of the Law written in their hearts their conscience also bearing witness and their thoughts the mean while accusing or else excusing one another. 16. In the day when God shall judge the secrets of men by Jesus Christ according to my Gospel”— The practise of taking double texts seems to have become a Fashion among the younger Clergymen of the Trinitarian Denomination. I somewhat doubt its propriety; it leads to the complication of the theme of the Discourse— The subject of Mr. Bartols sermon was the foundation of Religious Belief and the correspondent human action, but from his double text he drew a three fold impulse upon the agony of man—first Nature, secondly duty, thirdly Revelation The Discourse was argumentative and the reasoning forcible. His delivery was cold, and inanimate. The Text of his Afternoon Sermon was 1. Corinthians 7.31—[“]And they that use this World, as not abusing it”— The Doctrine drawn from this Text was, that this World was made for the use of man, but a Religion and morality were given him to preserve him from abusing it— Mr. Bartol dined with us. His is a graduate of Bowdoin College of the year 1831. I was obliged to ride to and from Meeting morning and afternoon. The storm of rain continued till the night.

13— V.  The Equinoxtial storm continued with heavy rain in the night and deprived me of the exercise both of walking and riding— It did not however deprive me of sleep nor of the power of reading in the day I confined it chiefly to the Universelle Religion par Dupuis— His system is that the source of all Religion including Christianity is the Worship of the Sun under various modified time, and he has long and tedious Commentaries upon the Deification of Hercules of Thesius and of Baccus— All degenerating into Fabulus Legions but all terminating in Astronomical phenomena—representing the annual course of the Sun connected with that of the moon. Dupuis is not the original inventor or discoverer of this System but he has spun it out into 12 or 14 volumes and with an array of antiquity never perhaps excuded— Col. George Bumford visited us, and dined with us, returning by the Cars to Boston after dinner at 1/2 past three oclock.

14. VI  I had a quiet night and slept till daylight this morning, and found a clear sky, when I rose, with cool Autumnal weather. Elizabeth. C. Adams returned this day from her excursion to Saratoga and New York, where she has been passing some time with her friend Mrs. Bartlett— I continue my reading as usual of Dupuis Universelle Religion and the Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation Evening ride to Braintree—

15— VI.  This day at 12 oclock was the Annual Meeting of the Supervisors of the Adams Temple and School Fund at Quincy. A Resolution had been adopted two years ago that the Annual Meeting should be held on the first Wednesday in September in the Select mens Room at the new Town Hall, and that if that day should by any accident pass over, without being held it should then be specially called as early in the month of September as might be. The first Wednesday of the month was passed over inattentively this year, but it was specially called by the President Mr. Thomas Greenleaf and was held this day— The members present were Thomas Greenleaf President, George. W. Beale, Charles. F. Adams and myself— Mr. Josiah Quincy Senior was not present. There was nothing to be done except the adjustment of the accounts of the Treasurer of the Corporation, who is also the Treasurer for the Town of Quincy, John Briesler— The Meeting adjourned before one oclock— There was another Meeting called a Pic Nic of children, otherwise a Temperance meeting calling themselves a Cold Water Army who had a collation at the Town Hall— To this Meeting I was invited and witnessed their assemblage to the number of about one hundred and twenty children of each sex between seven and fourteen years of age, who formed a procession issuing from the Town Hall and returning there to their Collation.— to which I did not stay. They had sundry addresses made to them and were still there when I rode by, up to Braintree and returning by Bens Point about sunset—

16. V.  Mrs. President Edward Everett came from Cambridge with her daughter, and Miss Barclay daughter of the British Consul at New York. Mr. Palfrey came and we all dined at my Sons house— After dinner they returned to Cambridge, and I rode with Mrs. John Adams and Miss Cutts to Milton returning by the way of Neponset. Miss Sampson has been here since Tuesday. While I was absent seven Ladies and gentlemen by the name of Sleeper paid me a visit, I did not see them— Two persons from the State of Maine one named Robinson the other Vail, very complimentary, as are indeed all my visitors, strangers who come to see me from motives of curiosity. I am under great obligations to them all, but give them no better than lenten entertainment. There was a bright Northern Light this Evening followed by a bright day.

There was a bright Northern Light this Evening— The Northern Light is some times a prognostic of rain within twenty four hours and sometimes of a bright sky for two days at least as it has now been We have now almost daily news of Battles and of the approach of our Army to the City of Mexico, and of Peace, which must immediately follow upon that event— My two last nights have not been so quiet and some that preceeded them. I walked this day round the long Square. I rode this Evening with Mrs. John Adams and Miss Cutts to Braintree returning by the Bent’s Point Methodist Church. Dr. Woodward was here and somewhat modified his prescriptions My Granddaughter received a Letter from Mr. Christopher Hughes who is at Chester Springs in Pennsylvania, somewhat of an Invalid and part of the time perhaps as much indisposed as I am. His case is more full of hopes, but perhaps as precarious as my own.

18. VI.  A Clergyman by the name of Curtis from Milwaukie from the Territory or State of Wisconsin, came this morng. pedling a volume by I A Lapam entitled Wisconsin its Geography and Topography &c— For which he claimed three quarters of a dollar, and solicited a contribution for erecting a Congregational Church at Milwaukie. I took his book, but thought the people of Milwaukie had better build their own Congregational Church. He said there were large numbers there about erecting a Roman Catholic Church mostly Germans. A number of Roman Catholics from Germany as well as from Ireland, is very great, in our New Western States and in the course of a few years will outnumber all other Denominations. I had a very unquiet and dejected night and my Granddaughter Mary Louisa is also quite indisposed, with a severe cold. I rode this Evening with my wife and Mrs. Charles Adams round Braintree.

20. VI.  The Revd. Nathaniel Hall Minister of the Congregational Church Dorchester preached by exchange with Mr. Lunt. His morning text was from Ecclesiastes 1.3 [“]What profit hath a man of all his labor which he taketh under the Sun”— The peculiarity of the Discourse was that it was an elaborate argument against the principle of the text itself maintaining, that there is profit in all the labor of man. The text of the afternoon was from Hebrews 6.5. “The powers of the world to come”—a theme of awful solemnity— Mr. Hall has no pretension to eloquence of manner, but his composition is very good— He dined with us, but we had no evening visitors—

21. VI.  The Revd. Calvin Durfee was here this morning with his son a boy of ten or eleven years of age—he brought with him an Album in which I had written some things concerning my birth and lineage to which he requested me now to make an addition, which I accordingly did— Shortly before we had dined Mr. Joshua Dodge heretofore Consul of the United States at Bremen, and afterwards an Agent for negotiating with the Germanic Princes concerning duties upon Tobacco, came having already dined before he left Boston but remained and took Tea with us. Mr. Charles Sumner, and Mr. Ellis Gray Loring also came out after dinner took Tea with us and the three gentlemen returned by the Cars of six oclock. I walked round the long square before dinner but was obliged to retire part of the afternoon to my Couch— My son was here in the Eveg— Mr. Sumner and Mr. Loring left with me a draft of a Letter, which they proposed to me to write containing sundry enquiries to be addressed with the consent of the British Government to the Governors of all their West India Colonies, requesting statements of their actual condition consequent upon the abolition of Slavery in each of the Islands— I received the paper with a promise to take it into consideration, but suggesting some difficulties which I thought there would be, to my entering into such a correspondence. I received also a Letter from Joseph Follensby heretofore Door Keeper to the House of Representatives of the House of Representatives stating that he proposes offering himself as a Candidate for that Office and asking my favorable consideration, to which he is fully entitled. I received also, a Letter from Mrs. Waterhouse repeating her request heretofore made for Letters received by me, from her husband during his life time. My Son was here, and told me that President Edward Everett was sick in bed, and could of course not attend at the meeting tomorrow of the Committee of the Board of Overseers of Harvard University on the Observatory—  Rain great part of the night, and part of this morng I had a very indifferent night. I took it for granted that Mr. Quincy would not be able to attend at the Meeting of the Committee on the Observatory. that President Everett would be equally disabled and the weather being very unpromising I reluctantly renounced the attempt to go The weather was very equivocal all day between storm and sunshine, but I walked round the long Square before dinner. I read besides my usual portion of Dupuis Universelle Religion the projected Letter upon British Emancipation left with me by Mr. Charles Sumner and Mr. Ellis. G. Loring.

22. VI  The weather cleared off and we had a fine day— I went in the Carriage to Boston with Mrs. C. F. Adams, Miss Louisa C. Smith, and Miss Cutts, stopt of the way at Mr. Quincy house—he had been at my house yesterday afternoon, but I was lying down and did not see him. Not knowing whether the members of the Committee of the Board of Overseers of Boston had visited the Observatory yesterday or not—this was first to be ascertained— I left the Carriage in Summer Street and walked to the Counting house of Abbott and Amos Lawrence in Milk Street, but Mr Abbott Lawrence was not there neither did I see him— He was attending a meeting of the Directors of a Seamans Saving Bank where I endeavored to find him but without success. I went to my sons Office No 23. Court St. and found a number of gentlemen there in consultation with him prepatory to a meeting of a State Convention of the Whigs to be held at Springfield on the 29th. of this month. While there I received from Mr. J. Ingersoll Bowditch the Report of the Committee of the Board of Overseers of the Observatory, made yesterday and signed by Messrs David Sears, Abbott Lawrence, J Ingersoll Bowditch and Francis Peabody, who actually met—received the Reports of the Perkins Professor of Astronomy and mathematics—Pearce and of the Observer W. C. Bond and made the Report to the Board of Overseers, to be submitted at the session of the Legislature next Winter. From my Sons Office I proceeded, to the Revd. Dr. N. L. Frothinghams, where I had agreed to meet the ladies, to return to Quincy— I found Dr. Frothingham at home but he was obliged to go out at one oclock to a christening— I could have but a very short conversation with him and at half past one we left his house and returned to Quincy— My son and his daughter Louisa went this Evening to Boston to the Opera. and we were left at home. Isaac. Hull. Adams. dined with us; and Elizabeth Adams was here last Evening. I received a Letter from H. G. Sommerby, who proposes to go to England, to investigate the pedigrees of the early settlers of New England— I read the Report of the Committee who visited the Observatory yesterday and the Reports of the Perkins Professor and of the Observer William. C. Bond to them, deeply regretting my failure to attend at the meeting and that of Mr. Quincy consequent upon mine— There is yet one Astronomical Instrument to be received from England and mounted for the complete organization of the Observatory—

23— VI  After a somewhat restless and uneasy night, I was enabled to take my usual walk this morning— A man by the name of John Smith a Quaker from the Island of Barbadoes came as a mendicant for assistance to return to that Island—with a certificate from Henry Baker of Providence Rhode Island and recommending him as a member of the Methodist Episcopal Church Before he was gone came Capt Matthias Rich from Cape Cod, blind, with his son a boy of ten or twelve years of age and with a recommendaty Certificate from Dr. Reynolds of Boston— Of this Class of Certificated mendicants scarcely one day ever passes but one or more presents himself, and of that sort of beggary I believe there is at least as much in this Country as in any part of Europe— The greater number of them are Europeans but there is no scarcity of them natives of our own Soil— I had also a visit from Mr. Whitney who has before Congress, a Petition and project for the construction of a Railway from Lake Michigan to the South Sea in the Territory of Oregon— He presented it first I think at the first Session of the last Congress and reports favorable to it, were made at the last Session of Congress— I was in favor of it myself and gave it what encouragement I could— He bespoke my influence in favor of it still, and entered into some details upon which I told him I could not as yet form any decided opinion but which I should not be found disposed to meet with unreasonable objections— He spent as much as two hours with me in discussing his own peculiar views on the subject, but in favor of which I could only promise a good will— I attended this Evening the Party given by Mr. & Mrs. Lunt to their whole parish and of which he gave the invitation in the Pulpit last Sunday. I remained there about an hour. The house was crowded with the Company, with a small portion of which I was personally acquainted; among them some whom I have known from my earliest childhood— We came home between nine and ten oclock in the Evening—

24. VI.  Miss Cutts went to Boston and dined at Dr. Warrens, and returned by the Cars at 6. Oclock. Mrs. John Adams was confined the whole day to her bed by indisposition. Mrs. J. Q. Adams, C. F. Adams his wife, Louisa Catherine and Mary Louisa went to Boston this afternoon in the Carriage to see the Italian Opera of Hernani— They got home about half past eleven at night.

I propose, to examine my Files of Papers, and to minute down in this Diary those which I shall successively examine and for which I shall ask the assistance of my Grand daughter. The Revd. Samuel K. Lothrop came and introduced a Mr. Hincks an native of Ireland but who comes as a . . . from London. Mr. Hincks returned to Boston by the Railway Cars but Mr. Lothrop returned to his Summer residence on Milton Hill. I walked round the Long Square but was disappointed of my evening ride— Continued reading in the Universelle Religion of Dupuis which leads me deeper and deeper into confusion—

25— VI  A stormy day and night. Mr. Lunt preached to very thin auditory—his morng text was from Mark 3.1. [“]And he entered again into the Synagogue and there was a man there which had a withered hand”— This was the occasion upon they watched Jesus whether he would heal the man’s withered hand on the Sabbath day—their purpose being to make it a charge against him He did heal the man’s hand and the Pharisees took counsel with the Herodians how they might destroy him. He had in defence of himself laid down as the real law sanctifying, the Sabbath that the sabbath was made for man—and not man for the Sabbath that it is lawful to do good on the Sabbath-day, putting it to them in the form of a question which they dared not answer— He recurred to the example of David whom he considered as justified in a double violation of the Levitical Law, not only by eating to appease his hunger but by taking the shewbread which none but the Priests were obliged to eat. Mr. Lunt did not much enlarge upon this point of view but rather dilated by a description of the great power conferred upon man by the exercise of the hand, and the great abridgment of all the powers of man when deprived of the use of hand— The afternoon text was from Matthew 13.18. “Hear ye therefore the parable of the sower.” One of the many Discourses upon which the moral principles of Christianity were founded. Lieut Joseph. H. Adams who is stationed at Charlestown came and dined with us, but the foul weather confined all our Ladies at home.

26. VI.  Another stormy Night and day— Jonathan Cummings paid me a morning visit before our Breakfast, though he himself had Breakfasted at his Sons house which formerly belonged to Anthony Baxter Mr. Cummings the Father lives at Plymouth on the Merrimac River in the County of Grafton in the State of New Hampshire He was born at Concord in that same State in 1774. the first year of the Revolutionary War. His father removed not long afterwards to his present residence which at that time was in the midst of a wilderness, though now in the center of . . . Railroads I received a Letter from Joseph N. Brewer of the City of Roxbury enclosing a Report made by Genl. H. A. S. Dearborn the mayor to the City Council of this City in favor of a Public Cemetery— A Letter from Freeman Hunt Editor of the Merchant’s Magazine a Periodical publication requesting me for a Certificate of my opinion in favor of that work. And one from R. C. Washington of Washington announcing himself as a Candidate for the Office of Doorkeeper of the House of Representatives of the United States— I walked before dinner round the short Railway square not without being overtaken by a shower of rain. I rode in the Evening with Mrs. Charles Adams and Miss Cutts round Milton Hill. My Son was afterwards here in the Evening—

28. VI.  A man by the name of Peter D Waldelaar, came as a mendicant claiming to be a relation of Mr. Van Vechten of Albany— He claimed also to be coming now from the State of Ohio and solicited contribution for some Public Institution the object of which he could not explain. He took however a refusal very quietly and departed I received from the Revd. William. D. Sprague D.D. a Discourse on the death of the Hon Silas Wright late Governor of the State of New York delivered in the 2d. Presbyterian Church at Albany on the 5th. of the present month. Mr: Wright died of apoplexy on theday of August. The storm subsided. I walked round the long Square before dinner. Ride to South Braintree and Weymouth with Mrs. Charles. Miss Cutts left us to take Tea with Elizabeth. C. Adams. My son stays over night in Boston to go early tomorrow morning to the Whig State Convention at Springfield.

29. VI.  I received a Letter from John. C. King a Sculptor who in the Summer of 1845. model’d my Bust at Boston. He complains that he had only eight subscribers for casts but that an Italian Pedlar he fears has got one of them and is pirating copies of it at a cheaper price than he can afford He desires an improvement of the Patent Laws extending to Sculptors, the privileges granted to Authors and asks for my written opinion of my Bust made by him. I walked round the Square before dinner, and afterwards rode with Mrs. John Adams and Mrs. Charles with her little Mary to the Biscuit Bakers at Milton. Mrs. Charles Adams spent the Evening here.

30. VI.  College an Institution of three years standing, came with a Letter introductory from the Reverend John Pierce of Brookline. Mr. D. Graham is on his first visit to New England to present the claims of his Seminary to Public favor— Mr. Jenkins of Roxbury came with him. I declined a contribution to the Central College of Michigan but gave him at his request an Autograph Signature. I received a Letter from J. W. Johnson dated Dartmouth College Hanover New Hampshire 25 September 1847 requesting an Autograph, with a swelling compliment. I walked round the long Square before dinner and dined with Mrs. Charles Adams, with the expectation that my son would have returned from Springfield, but he did not reach home till after dinner. A Mrs. Hale from Weathersfield Connecticut paid us a visit with her son Joseph Hale, who resides at Boston, her visit was one of curiosity We had also visits from Mrs. G. T. Bigelow and her brother Charles Miller who proposes to embark tomorrow in the Steamer Britania for England. I rode with Mrs Charles F. Adams and Mrs. John Adams round to Milton returning by the Neponset Bridge Turnpike. My Son and his wife passed the Evening with us.

1. VI.  Dr. Woodward was here this morning and recommended a new modification of my daily Medicines Hucsams Tincture to be taken twice a day and also when I could find it convenient to take Galvanic attacks, but no medicine has much effect upon me. Edmund Chadwick A.M. came to solicit contributions for Starkey Seminary Yates County. New York. I gave him a copy of my Letters on Free Masonry not for the Starkey Seminary but for himself— I took my daily ride before dinner with Mrs. Charles her Mary and Miss Cutts I dined at my Sons up the hill and walked round the long Square at sunset— My Wife, Mrs. John, Miss Cutts and Mary Louisa, with my son and his daughter Louisa Catherine all went to Boston to see the Italian Opera Corrado Altamura at the Howard street Theatre They got home just before midnight— Mrs. C. F. Adams came and spent the Evening with me till nine oclock and read to me a long story about Mr. Peabody and my Aunt his wife— Elizabeth. C. Adams and Isaac. Hull. spent the Evening with us.

2. VI.  A fine night and frosty morning, but I was more indisposed than I have been for some time— I received a Letter from John. S. H Fogg dated South Berwick Maine, who requests for a literary Institution an Autograph of my Father and of any other of the other Presidents of the United States— I received a printed Circular Invitation from Elias G. Drake Hamilton Fish Wm. Hall Joseph C. Hart and Calvin Pollard Committee of Arrangements of the Washington Monument association of the City of New York to attend at the laying of the Corner stone of the Monument on the 19th. of the present month of October anniversary of the Surrender of Cornwallis 19th. October 1781. with a request for an early answer Sunset ride with Mrs. John Adams, Mrs. Charles, and Miss Cutts round the Braintree Depot— My Son with his wife and daughter Louisa were here in the Evening.

3. VI  An uneasy comfortless night Mr. Lunt administered the Communion and preached from Luke 13.23— “Then said one unto Him Lord are there few that be saved and He said unto them. 24. Strive to enter in at the straight gate for many I say unto you will seek to enter in and shall not be able”— It is remarkable that a direct answer to the question is evaded instead of it is an implied censure upon the question itself and a strong exhortation to the hearers instead of busying themselves with inquiries as to the number of those that should be saved to confine their attention to the means of securing their own Salvation. The Discourse was elaborate and impressive— That of the afternoon was by Mr. Simmons from Matthew 11.11. [“]Verily I say unto you among them that are born of women there hath not risen a greater than John the Baptist, notwithstanding he that is least in the Kingdom of Heaven is greater than he”—an interesting Discourse upon the character of John the Baptist. There is a German Essayist by the name of Fuster who in a Review of the Gallery of Pictures at Dresden has selected an imaginary Portrait of John the Baptist, as the subject of a dissertation upon the character of this wonderful personage, which I think Mr. Simmons must have read, and from which he must have borrowed many ideas in portraying this forerunner of the Messiah, deserving of the profound meditation of every pious Christian. Mr. Loring of Hingham was at the afternoon service and paid me afterwards a visit. Mrs. Loring being at Mr. John Greenleafs— Mr. Quincy was here in the Evening, and proposed to take some fair day to visit the Observatory at Cambridge to make up our failure to attend with the Committee of the Board of Overseers on the 21st. of September My son and his wife were also here this Evening. Fine day. I walked to and from meeting this morng—

4. VI.  A cheerless and uncomfortable night. My Wife Mrs. John Adams, Miss Cutts and Mary Louisa, went to Boston this morning and returned to dine. Miss Cutts had intended to leave us and go for Washington this day with the Trist family, who left Boston this afternoon but she was disappointed— Col Bomford was here to accompany her but she was equally disappointed in not being able to go with him. I was out upon my morning walk when he was here and did not see him. Miss Elizabeth Susan Quincy, and Miss Abby Quincy, were also here and I requested them to propose to their Father to go on an expedition to visit the Observatory next Thursday if the weather shall permit— I received in the Evening a note from Miss Quincy accepting this proposition of which Mr. Quincy engages to give notice to President Edward Everett. In addition to my reading of Dupuis Universelle Religion, through the slow length of which I am continuing to drag. I have this day undertaken to read Lord Brougham translation of the Oration of Demosthenes for the Crown. The time of the daily passage of the Railway Cars between Boston and Quincy was this day changed and instead of arriving at a quarter before three P.M. it now comes at a quarter past four, so that when we called for Mrs. Charles at half past four she was at dinner and did not go with us— Miss Louisa. C. Smith and Miss Cutts rode with me to Milton returning by the Neponset Turnpike— My Son and his wife were here in the Evening and also our neighbours Mr. and Mrs. Emmons— The accounts were received this day of the taking of the City of Mexico by General Scott on the 17th. of September.

5— VI.  I had a more quiet and comfortable night than for several preceeding days. We have had several frosty mornings and the weather continues fair— I took a ride before dinner with Mr. Dehone of New York, and Mrs. Charles Adams, to the Quarries, where we alighted and surveyed the work— I dined with Mr. Dehone at my sons house At five oclock Mr. Dehone returned to Boston by the Railway— In the Evening my Son and his wife were here.

6. VI.  Walk round the long Square before dinner, met and walked with Price Greenleaf— Received five printed Tracts on Poverty, Prosperity and Religion united. Letter from Henry Gassett enclosing one from Benjamin Ferris Bonair Hartford Md. 9. month 25. 1847. to him. Mr. Ferris wants to get a present of a book to me, which requires an answer from me to Mr. Gassett, but I had not time to have written it to day— Miss Cutts left us this day and went to Boston and from thence by the Fall River Railway to return to Washington. Mr. Robinson the Episcopal Clergyman who was some time settled here visited me this Day and told me he was happily settled in a Seamens Church at Boston— Mr.came with Mr. Robinson, and I gave him at his request an Autograph.

7. VI.  I had a very indifferent nights rest and scarcely expect any other. I nevertheless rose this morning, rather earlier than is my custom now. Breakfasted, and at eight oclock this morning, called in my Carriage at Mr. Josiah Quincys and took him with me to visit the Observatory at Cambridge, the other Members of the Committee of the Board of Overseers, namely David Sears, Abbott Lawrence J. Ingersoll Bowditch and Francis Peabody did pay the visit on the 21st. of September and made a Report thereof to be returned with Reports from the Perkins Professor of Astronomy and Mathematics Mr. Pierce and from Wm. C. Bond, the Observator to be returned to the Board of Overseers during the approaching Winter Session of the General Court. In consequence of my own personal indisposition, of that of President Quincy suffering from inflammation of the eyes, of President Everett who was that day confined to his Bed by sickness and of a threatened storm in the morning, I was deterred from calling upon Mr. Quincy to proceed to Cambridge on that day as we had agreed. We were disappointed accordingly in attending with the other Members of the Committee and substituted a visit of this day, for our own satisfaction— We reached Cambridge at ten oclock and President Everett went with us to the Observatory, where we found the Observator William. Cranch. Bond. and his son and Assistant George. C. Bond—but Professor Pierce was not there. The great Frauenhofer Refractor a small Transit Instrument and a very complete Comet seeker were all there perfectly mounted. The large Equatorial upon a very Capital stone pier. There is however one large Transit Instrument to be constructed by Simms at London which has not yet arrived and seems to have been too long delayed. one of the Glasses having disappointed the Maker himself so that he concluded to make another. The sky though clear early this morning had clouded up before we reached the Observatory, and we could take no view through the principal Instrument About twelve oclock we returned to President Everetts and then home. I left Mr. Quincy at his house and reached my own before three oclock in time for dinner— In the Afternoon I took a solitary walk, and my Son and his Wife were here in the Evening— Elizabeth Adams and Isaac Hull were also here— In our ride this morning, I had a conversation with Mr. Quincy in which, I suggested to him the expediency, of preparing a plan for organizing the Observatory with reference to its two distinct objects, first, as an Astronomical Observatory, for the assiduous cultivation of the Science of Astronomy, and Secondly, as a Branch of the Institution for Education of the youths of this Commonwealth— I thought it required a two fold organization having reference to both its objects one being the cultivation of the Science and the other the instruction of the Students at the University. Mr. Quincy concurred with me, in this view, and I intended to have conversed with the President, and him together, but we had not time sufficient for it— I spoke of it to Mr. Everett, but the difficulty immediately occurred to him of the want of Funds. He said the University had already incurred an expense of thirty two thousand dollars in addition to the donations which had been applied to this object, and that no provision had yet been made for the support of an Observator. There is yet much to be done and little encouragement before this Institution can be made to answer its complicated purposes—

8. VI.  I had a more comfortable night, but the day threatened a storm. Mr. Emmons called here, with two Volumes of Rogers Poems, which he proposes to present to Mr.Meredith, and he requested me to write some lines, but without saying what by way of autograph. I wrote accordingly a very few lines expressing my opinion of Rogers, as the most pleasing English Poet of the present Century. I remember reading the Pleasures of Memory at the time of its first publication. I think as early as 1793. and they gave me more pleasure than any of the Poems of Cowper, Burns, in any of the De la cruscan writers of the same period, and much more than Southey or Peter Pindar at that time more popular than all the rest, and now almost totally forgotten. I was personally acquainted with Mr. Rogers at that time and met him several times in Society though not at his own house— Campbell was of rather a later date, Walter Scott still later. Byron and Shelley last of all. Coleridge and Wordsworth are hardly to be included in the Catalogue and of some later Poet Tasters I cannot charge my memory with their names. I ask the pardon of Mr. Moore upon the whole the one who will last the longest of them all with filmy, gauzy, glossamary lines. as Darwin was characterized by the author of the once famous Pursuits of Literature. I took a ride with my Wife and Mrs. Charles

9. VI.  I walked yesterday morning to the Quincy Stone Bank. to deposit there a check for one hundred dollars given me by my son and to draw for two hundred, one for my wife, and one for Mrs. John for our current household expenses but though in banking hours I found the door locked and a paper pasted on it that the Cashier was gone to Boston but would be back at twelve oclock—a poor sample of Bank punctuality— I returned again this day and found the Cashier Bartlett at the Counter. I deposited the Check given me by my son, and drew one hundred dollars in Bills of the Bank, which I gave to Mrs. John, for the household expenses, and another of one hundred dollars which I paid in gold to my Wife, being the Sum which I borrowed of her last Summer, when we came from Washington— I walked before dinner round the Railway Square and after dinner—with Mrs. John and Mrs. Charles, I took Miss Sampson to her home at Braintree— I wrote the lines in the Vol of Rogers Poems to my great annoyance. I am almost entirely physically disabled from writing, and find it an insupportable task to be called upon for an autograph.

10— VI.  Revd. John H. Morison preached by exchange with Mr. Lunt. His morning text was from Hebrews 12.1. “Wherefore seeing we also are compassed about with so great a cloud of witnesses let us lay aside every weight and the sin which doth so easily beset us, and let us run with patience the race that is set before us.” From some of his preliminary remarks I expected that he was about to give us a funeral Discourse, but it did not appear to have reference to the decease of any individual, but considered all the persons with whom we had been acquainted who have gone to the World of Spirits as constituting this cloud of witnesses. Mr. Morison dined with us, and the text of his afternoon Discourse was from John 4.32. “But he said unto them I have meat to eat, that ye know not of.” I walked to and from Meeting morning and Afternoon and with more power to walk than I have had for some months. Mr. Beale with his two daughters spent part of the Evening with us—as did also my son and his wife.

11. VI.  We had no visitors this day— I walked round the Long Railway Square before dinner— Rode to Braintree with Mrs. John, and Mrs. Charles. F. Adams— I have received a Letter from Robert E. H. Lovering dated September 2nd. 1847. Lancaster Ohio post marked October 3d., enclosing several newspaper slips of Mr. Loverings Poetry. I gave him some years since a Letter of introduction to Col Aspinwall the Consul of the United States at London—he says, it aided him materially, in prosecuting his Antiquarian researches at the British Museum, that he has now sundry manuscripts arranged in publishable order, but that his funds are exhausted by his trip to Europe and he cannot publish them in a Volume. He wants one hundred dollars to aid him in this purpose and send it to him as soon as possible by the Mail which he will return at the proper time. He proposes also to aid me, in writing and to borrow money also for that purpose— I answered his Letter declining all his proposals. My son and his wife were here in the Evening

12.  A fine day. My wife, with Mrs. Charles Adams and my Granddaughter Mary Louisa, went to Boston and returned to dine— I walked round the long Railway Square before dinner but lost my afternoon ride— I recd a Letter from Ezekiel Bacon Utica New York the 8th. October 1847 about the leading Article of the Democratic Review of this month of October. My son was here this Evening without his wife.

13. VI.  A stormy night, sleepless, hopeless. Received a Letter from President Edward Everett with copies of two Reports to him from the Director of the Observatory William C. Bond one of the 26th. July, and the other of 22d. September 1847. Lieut Joseph H. Adams, was here this morning and went before dinner to Charlestown where he is stationed. The weather all the morning was so showery that I could not go out. Received a Letter from John Russell Bartlett New York 6. Octr. 1847. with a pamphlet by him on the Progress of Ethnology—which he has read to the New York Historical Society—received a Pamphlet Proceedings of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, containing Professor Pierce notice of Mr. Sears. C. Walkers discovery that the Planet Neptune was observed as a Fixed Star on the 10th. of May 1795. from which Prof Pierce infers, that the Planet Neptune though predicted by Leverrier was not the Planet which he predicted but another which ought not to have been found where he foretold it would be which is much like Moliere’swho upon being told that the heart is on the right side and the Liver is on the left says “nous avons changé toute cela.[”] Afternoon ride with my wife Mrs. Charles and her daughter Mary. Left Mary Louisa to pass the night with Elizabeth. C. Adams— my son here alone in the Eveg

14. VI.  No Supper last night— Slept this morning till daylight. Received a Letter from W. J. Mc.Cormick formerly Postmaster to the House of Representatives of the United States, dismissed by the Democratic House in 1843. and now again a Candidate for election to that Office. Walk round the long Railway Square. Reading Dupuis on the Eleusinian mysteries and all the Ancient initiations including those of the Christian Religion. Ride round Milton Hill with my wife, Mrs. Charles and Mary. My son and his wife here this Evening—

15. VI  After a fortunate day, had but half a nights sleep Andrews the fishmonger here this morning, I took a Rock Cod— Reading Lord Brougham’s Translation of the Oration of Demosthenes for the Crown, which I find about as hard to understand as the Original— I received the Protestant Quarterly Review for October 1847. and an account of a Taylor Meeting in Scott County Ky, no date General Zachary Taylor nominated for President of the United States. Walk round the long Railway Square. Mrs. Beck from Charlestown was here—she has a Petition before Congress for a Pension for her deceased mother which was rejected Winter before last and which she desires to have renewed at the approaching Session of Congress— She applies also for charity and told me she meant to apply to Col Perkins. visit from Mrs. Josiah Quincy and Miss Abby Quincy. they move to Boston for the Winter next Monday— Afternoon ride with my wife Mrs. Charles and little Mary on the road to Squantum by the spot where Mr. Appleton is about to build a house.

16. VI  Quiet and comfortable night. Frosty and beautiful morning My wife went with Mary Louisa to Boston. One returned to dinner, the other after dinner Morning visits from the Rev Mr. Loring from the State of Maine and from the Revd. Mr. Harding of the Railway Village Church Milton. Meridian walk across the Lane round the Long Railway Square— I met lying on the side of the lane on this side of my sons house Joshua Yeamans with papers a claimant for a Pension for services in the last War with Great Britain. he showed me one of his Papers a Certificate from his Captain Samuel Hough— I told him he must take his Papers to Washington and I would aid if it should be in my power. Received a Letter from Mr. Frye Washington 12th. Oct. 1847. Columbia Mills damaged by a great flood— I rode after dinner with Mrs. Charles and her Mary to Braintree and we took Miss Sampson home. My son and his wife were here till nine oclock.

17. VI.  A quiet night and beautiful October day Mr. Lunt preached this morning from Mark 12.42.43. [“]And there came a certain poor widow, and she threw in two mites, which make a farthing— 43. And he called unto him his disciples and saith unto them, Verily I say unto you, That this poor widow hath cast more in than they all they which have cast into the treasury”—and in the Afternoon from Revelation 5.6. “And I beheld, and lo, in the midst of the throne and of the four beasts, and in the midst of the elders, stood a Lamb, as it had been slain, having seven horns and seven eyes, which are the seven Spirits of God sent forth into all the earth.” Evening visit from Mr. Josiah Quincy and my son was here till the ringing of the Bell— I walked to and from Meeting Morning and Afternoon.

18. VI.  Paradise Lost 4. 675.  This is said by Adam to Eve in conversation, it does not absolutely appear that it expresses Miltons opinion of man in his fallen state but it contains the avowed belief of Emanuel Swedenborg and of his Sectarians. That communion with Spiritual Beings may have been one of the enjoyments of Adam in Paradise, I have right to deny though it would seem that it was not enjoyed at least with equal clearness by Eve. He asserts the fact as a thing not before known to her and yet he reminds her that they have heard these Celestial voices from the “steep of echoing hill or thicket, singing their great Creator”— However it may have been with Adam. I believe it was but a delusive dream in in Swedenborg. the existence of intelligent Spiritual Beings I cannot deny nor affirm—as a part of the Christian Religion it is a subject of belief, but not of proof and of the present state of the world— I never have heard “Celestial voices Singing to the midnight air” nor do I believe that any other human being in possession of his senses has heard them. These lines however gave occasion to much reflection in my mind this day. My Grandaughter Mary Louisa went with Mrs. Miller and Mrs. George T. Bigelow to Charlestown to visit Lieut Joseph. H. Adams in charge of the Ship Franklin— They returned this Afternoon— I took my morng walk and afternoon ride with my wife Mrs. Charles and her Mary round Milton Hill— Charles daughter Louisa dined with us— I received from Aaron. H. Palmer six copies of a Prospectus of the Unknown Countries of the East, i.e. the principal Countries of Eastern Africa and Asia— Also a Letter from Joseph Henry Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution dated Princeton 13th. October 1847. and enclosing a printed Paper of general considerations which should serve as a guide in adopting a plan of organization I suppose the Institution is already Organized by an Act of Congress under which this Mr. Joseph Henry has been appointed the Secretary—but he has a different plan of organization which is evidently sliding into a job— My son and his wife were here in the Evening— I received also from Revd. Mr. Clarke rector of Christ Church Quincy to which paper I subscribed some time since for five dollars which I now paid.

19. VI.  Anniversary of the Surrender of Cornwallis at Yorktown At New York the day celebrated by laying the Corner Stone of a monument to the memory of George Washington. The Corner Stone was laid by the Governor of the State Young and Addresses were made by the Chief Justice Jones and Col J. C. Hart— There was an Exhibition at the University of Cambridge. My Granddaughter went with Mrs. Miller and Mrs. George T. Bigelow and came home late this Evening. My Wife dined and drank Tea at my Sons up the hill. We took a ride towards Evening. The Steamer Cambria arrived at Boston this morning. Alexander. H. Everett died at Canton in China the 29th. of last June. Peace to his remains. I introduced him to Public life and had a very high opinion of his talents, from which I once formed great expectations, they have ended in sad disappointment. He died in a somewhat eminent Public Office, though not with the character of independent spirit which I once hoped for him.

20— VI.  Awake long before daylight I walked up the Hill and spoke with my son before he went to Boston. I wrote to R. G. Metcalf Representative of the Town of Wrentham in the State Legislature asking information of him to enable me to answer a Letter which I have received from W. J. Brown 2d. Assistant Postmaster General asking advice for the location of the Post Office at West Wrentham Elizabeth. C. Adams, Isaac Hull Adams, and Lieut Joseph. H. Adams. dined with us— Elizabeth rode with us after dinner round Milton Hill returning by the Neponset Bridge Turnpike. While we were out Mr. Joseph Russell of Boston paid us a visit. we did not see him— A Mr. Ewer a member of the Massachusetts Historical and Genealogical Society was also here— I gave him a printed Engraving byof Stuarts last Portrait of my Father, also an Engraved Profile of General Washington given me by Christopher Hughes. My son and his wife passed the Evening here. and Elizabeth took leave of us going tomorrow with her Uncle Joseph Harrod for N. Orleans—

21. VI.  A nearly sleepless and much distressed night Mary Louisa went this morning to the Railway Depot and saw the departure of Elizabeth C. Adams for New Orleans. Dr. William. B. Duggan and Capt Charles Swift were here. Captain Swift is a Candidate for the appointment of Light House Keeper of a new Light House to be erected on Minotts Ledge of the Cohasset Rocks or of any other Light House within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts— His application is already made to the Secretary of the Treasury with a numerously signed recommendation in his favor. he requested also mine. I received a Letter from Matthew Saint Clair Clarke with a Circular announcing himself as a Candidate for the Office of Clerk of the House of Representatives of the United States for the 30th. Congress— But the Clerk of the last Congress B. B. French is a very excellent Officer and in making application took time by the forelock in advance of Mr. Clarke— I walked round the long Railway Square before dinner but scarcely able to drag one leg before the other. Evening ride

22 VI.  I had a comparitively quiet night and slept till nearly daylight. I began a Letter to President Edward Everet to send with the Report of the Committee of the Board of Overseers on the Observatory but I was not able to finish it. Dr. Woodward was here this fore noon with a Galvanic Battery the effect of which he proposes to try upon my complaint— He gave me a very slight shock which appeared to me to produce little or no effect— I rode this afternoon from four till dark. Isaac Hull Adams was here this Evening. And my son with his wife.

23. VI.  There was rain great part of the night, which cleared off this morning I had a night of tolerable repose but in walking this morng after the rain had ceased found myself weaker than I have yet been, and was unable to extend my walk more than round the short Railway Square. The dampness of the atmosphere affects me most unfavorably. I received a note from the Revd. Matthew Hale Smith with a small Volume containing the four Sermons addressed to young persons and delivered in Washington in April 1846. Immediately before he left the 2nd. Presbyterian Church. Prefixed to the Volume is a note with a fac-simile of the resolution of the Congregation of the 2nd. Presbyterian Church adopted at my Motion on the 10th. May 1846. and the Title page announces this, as the fifth Edition of the work. It has also my Letter to him of the 7th. May 1846. Mr. Matthew Hale Smith is now the minister of a Congregational Society in Boston—and has become involved in a controversy with Mr. Mann the Secretary School Commission.

24. VI  A young man from the Divinity School Cambridge named Capin preached for Mr. Lunt this morning from Acts 1.8—on the gift of Tongues conferred upon the Apostles on the day of Pentecost by the Holy Ghost—and this afternoon from James 4.14. Lieut Joseph Adams came from Charlestown and dined with us, but returned this Afternoon to his Ship the Franklin— My son spent the Evening here. his daughter Louisa Catherine has been much indisposed for the last ten days and is yet confined at home— Our Mary Louisa is afflicted with a Whitlow. I walked to and from Meeting morning and Afternoon—but my power of locomotion continues gradually to decay—

25. VI.  This is the day ever memorable to me the anniversary of my Fathers marriage on the 25th. October 1764. A day of happy memory but now introduced by a hapless half sleepless night succeeded by a cloudy day of variable weather alternate sunshine and shower and blowing the sirocco South west wind— I walked up the hill round the short Railway Square barely able to stand on my feet. I was called down to Old man named William Hunt a mendicant I received a Letter from William Clarkson Johnson son of my deceased brother Charles daughter the first wife of Alexander B. Johnson of Utica New York, informing me that he intends to be married during the first of next month to Miss Harriet Douw of Albany and immediately afterwards to embark for Europe to pass there the ensuing Winter and to return home to resume his business next Spring— I am still occupied upon a Letter to President Edward Everett.

26— VI.  Morning visit from Ex President Quincy whom I agreed to meet, if possible at the Meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society at Boston next Thursday—when I propose to communicate to him my Letter to President Edward Everett which I have not yet finished. My Son gave me a note for a thousand dollars from him to me for ninety days to be endorsed by me— Dr. Woodward was here and gave me a slight shock of the Galvanic Battery. which I shall take without any confidence in its efficacy or in my own power of using it. Afternoon ride to the Squantum road. I received from Mr. Charles Ewer the first three numbers of the New England Historical and Gennealogical Register published under the direction of the New England Historic Genealogical Society by the Revd. Wm. Cogswell D.D. Editor. Also Robert Cushman’s sermon on the Sin and Danger of Self-love, delivered at Plymouth in New England in December 1621.

27— VI.  Change in the night from the Southwest Summer to the North west Winter wind and Fahrenheit’s Thermometer this morning at Sunrise at 16. to me a half sleepless night Morning walk round the Long Railway Square and an afternoon ride with my wife and my Granddaughter Mary Louisa to Braintree, and round by Quincy Point. I received a Letter from Arnold Buffum New York 25th. October 1847. with a printed Circular convoking a World’s Convention to be held at New York to which convocation he requests my signature and my consent to preside at the Convention. which I must of course decline. I received also a printed Circular in behalf of the Farming Colored Association dated Northern Star Office Albany 18th. October 1847— This is a project for removing the Colored population to the new Western States— I received also a Letter from Caleb Mills Professor of Greek Wabash College Iowa Post marked Crawfordsville and requesting my opinion respecting the intention in appropriating every 36th. section of Land in the new States to Educational purposes. From which it appears that the State of Michigan differs on the Construction of this Law with the States of Ohio, and Indiana. and with it, the first number of a Periodical Journal entitled The Compact No 1. 16th. Octr. 1847. J. B. Jones Editor and Proprieter. the first Article of which relates to the preservation of the Union All these Papers are symptoms of the firmentation of Slavery in this Country. My son and his wife were here in the Eveg.

28. VI.  Another cold night— Thermometer said to have been in Boston as low as 12. Almost unexampled and I suffer with cold accordingly, but I nevertheless went with my wife and Louisa Catherine to Boston and attended the monthly meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society. It was half past twelve before I reached the Society’s apartment where about thirty members were present and the President was reading a Manuscript Letter to him from a gentleman in England containing numerous anecdotes concerning many individuals of the emigrations succeeding that of Governor Winthrop in 1632. and 1634. I heard only a part of this paper which prolonged the Session of this day till it was past two oclock— Among the Members present were Ex President Josiah Quincy and Mr. Robert. C. Winthrop recently returned from a voyage to England. I gave to Mr. Quincy the Report of the Committee of the Overseers of Harvard University on the Observatory with the annexed papers and my own Letter to President Edward Everett all to be reported to the Overseers at the next Winter Session of the Legislature— Mr. Quincy engaged to deliver or transmit them all to President Edward Everett. At the adjournment of the Meeting I walked to Dr. Frothingham’s house where I found my wife already in the Carriage at the door and returned home to Quincy to dinner. The cold of the night, had subsided but not so as to give me a comfortable Evening. Isaac Hull and Lieut. Joseph. H. Adams dined with us. and the former staid with us for the night. I had hoped to derive benefit from the exercise of the ride and the walk in Boston, but was disappointed and found myself quite unwell this night.

29. VI.  A wretched night and hopeless day— The weather continues unceasingly cold— I had visits from the Revd. Mr. Lunt, Mr. Josiah Brigham, & professionally from Dr. Woodward who gave me a shock of half an hour of the Galvanic Battery, from which I expect no relief. Mr. Lunt gave me a Manuscript heretofore Copied, by his Father of a Memoir of Mr. Shackford which Mr. Daniel Webster had communicated to the Late Judge John Davis. Mr. Brigham’s visit was to take leave of us in the expectation of our departing for Washington next Monday which God grant we may have power to do—

My son with his family moved to Boston for the Winter. I walked round the Railway Square but had no afternoon ride. Afternoon visit from Joseph Russell of Boston and also from Mr. Minott Thayer of Braintree. My condition remains as it has been for months

31. VI.  Mr. Capin a student at the Divinity School Cambridge preached for Mr. Lunt who was himself in the Pulpit, was from Acts 1.8. [“]But ye shall receive power after that the Holy Ghost is come upon you and ye shall be witnesses unto me both in Jerusalem and in all Judea and in Samaria and unto the uttermost parts of the earth.” and the Discourse was upon what is called the gift of tongues on the day of Pentecost conferred upon the Apostles—a subject which I think ought not to be discussed by any youthful Student at a Divinity School. Mr. Capin did not appear to have any settled opinion what this gift of Tongues was. he seemed to question whether it was a miraculous power to speak different languages. although that has been generally held to be the power precisely conferred. I cannot conceive indeed how the account in the Book of the Acts can be otherwise understood it says “When the day of Pentecost was fully come they were all with one accord in one place and suddenly there came a sound from Heaven as of a rushing mighty wind and it filled all the house where they were sitting and there appeared unto them cloven tongues like as of fire and it sat upon each of them and they were all filled with the Holy Ghost and began to speak with other tongues as the Spirit gave them utterance and there were dwelling at Jerusalem Jews, devout men out of every nation under Heaven now when this was noised abroad the multitude came together and were confounded because that every man heard them speak in their own language, and they were all amazed and marvelled saying one to another, behold are not all these which speak Gallalaeans and how hear we every man in our own tongue wherein we were born Parthians, and Medes, and Elamites and the dwellers in Mesopotamia and in Judea and Cappadocia, in Pontus and Asia Frigia and Pamphilia, in Egypt and in the parts of Lybia about Cyrene and strangers of Rome, Jews and proselytes. Cretes and Arabians we do hear them speak in our tongues the wonderful works of God. And they were all amazed and were in doubt saying one to another what meaneth this.” Nothing can be more explicit though to be sure others mocking said these men are full of new wine. Mr. Capin through some doubt over the whole transaction and made somewhat light of it considering the mere gift of speaking sundry languages as of not much importance and less connected with the other gift of prophecy— This afternoon Discourse was fromMr. Capin dined with us. and Mr. Degrand came out from Boston and dined with us also. Evening visits from Mr. & Mrs. Emmons and Mr. George Beale—

1. VI.  Went to Boston with Mary Louisa—shaved at No 222 Washington street. Cadmus has removed to Cambridge a man by the name of Bogle now keeps the shop 222. which for about ten years has been my place for shaving in Boston— I returned to my Sons house no 57. Mount Vernon Street and from thence we returned to Quincy to dine. At five P.M. we took the Railroad train of Cars for Fall River J. Q Adams, Louisa Catherine Adams, Mrs. John Adams, Mary Louisa & Isaac Hull Adams, Mrs. Eleanor Goods, Margaret Delany—and William Wheeler Coachman, eight persons— Lieut Joseph Harrod Adams goes with us as far as New York. It seemed to me on leaving home as if it was upon my last great journey— At 7. P.M. we reached Fall River and embarked in the Steamer Bay State. had but one moment to shake hands with Mr. Nathaniel Borden. We had a fine night, a brisk breeze but it was so dark that I saw nothing of the place and have no more idea of it than I ever had. The Boat is a remarkably fine one but I very soon turned in for the night to bed.

Our passage during the first part of the night particularly sound. Point Judith was somewhat rough and our fresh water sailor passengers were all seasick, but I slept it away in bed till near daylight this morning when we had got into the East River beyond Sands Point and approaching Hurl Gate, when a thick fog came up which brought us to lay to till long after sunrise. As the fog dispersed the Bay State resumed her course and about noon we landed in the North River and took lodgings at the Astor House— At the Astor House we found Mrs. Alexander. B. Johnson of Utica and her brother Mr. Masters. William C. Johnson was married last night to Miss Harriet Douw of Albany and they are expected to arrive here next Thursday and to embark for England next Monday. Alexander. S. Johnson called on us— Our ladies went to the Theater to see the French Ballet Dancers. Mr. John Jay and Mr. Beakman came, and took me with them to attend a numerous meeting of the New York Historical Society at which Albert Gallatin presided, and where several interesting Papers were read. My meeting with Mr. Gallatin was very pleasant and cordial— He Presided at the Meeting as if he had been forty years of age— I got home about ten P.M—

3—  Past the day at New York suffering as if every day would be my last and yet as if I were in the prime of life— We had very indifferent chambers given us yesterday and better this day— Mrs. DeWindt who has come and taken lodgings for the Winter in the City with her daughter Isabella and two children a boy and a girl of her other daughter the widow Mrs. Louisa Whittemore called on us. Mrs. Whittemore being detained at home by indisposition. Mr. Furman a gentleman to whom Isabella is engaged to be married also called. I had also visits from Mr. Arnold Buffam and sundry others whose names I do not recollect. The day slipt away I know not how suffering severely all the time with the tooth ache and feeling as if I was gradually breathing my last. Notwithstanding which, I went with the Ladies in the Evening to the Opera the Somnambula the part of Amina by Madame Anna Bishop, and the mad Musician from which we returned to our lodgings about eleven P.M.

4. VI.  At nine this morning we crossed the River to Jersey City and took the Railway Cars for Philadelphia where we arrived at two P.M. and took our lodgings at what was Jone’s Union Hotel— Still called by his name but he is no longer there I walked immediately alone to the Bank of North America which is still in Chesnut Street but on the other side of the Street from where it was before, and I received 150 dollars in gold for five Coupons of thirty dollars each on Cincinnati Bonds payable the first of November 1847— We dined and spent the Eveg at Philadelphia— Joseph Adams left us this morning

5. VI.  I had a tolerably quiet night and at eight oclock this morning we left the house still called Jones Hotel at Philadelphia and now kept as an appendage to the United States Hotel. We took this morning the Train of Railroad Cars for Baltimore, where we arrived at two oclock and found our friend Christopher Hughes as we alighted at the American House opposite the Railway Depot. There we dined and after dinner Mr. Hughes called on us again with his Daughter Margaret— I was tortured with the tooth ache and Margaret Delany had been seized with violent Cramps in the Cars this morning before we reached Baltimore— We took the Train for Washington which started at five P.M. and notwithstanding sundry obstacles and delays we reached our house in F street Washington about eight oclock this Evening. All safe, blessed be the name of God. Mrs. Swift wife of Capt Swift had travelled with us from U.S.

5. VI.  I had a tolerably quiet night and at eight oclock this morning we left the house still called Jones Hotel at Philadelphia and now kept as an appendage to the United States Hotel. We took this morning the Train of Railroad Cars for Baltimore, where we arrived at two oclock and found our friend Christopher Hughes as we alighted at the American House opposite the Railway Depot. There we dined and after dinner Mr. Hughes called on us again with his Daughter Margaret— I was tortured with the tooth ache and Margaret Delany had been seized with violent Cramps in the Cars this morning before we reached Baltimore— We took the Train for Washington which started at five P.M. and notwithstanding sundry obstacles and delays we reached our house in F street Washington about eight oclock this Evening. All safe, blessed be the name of God. Mrs. Swift wife of Capt Swift had travelled with us from U.S.

6. VII.  Thanks to Almighty God that I am yet alive—and may I be ready to surrender my soul at His call whenever it shall come— Mr. Frye called to see us this day Dr. Gunnell extracted the tooth from my head which relieved me from immediate and severe suffering I called at the Bank of the Metropolis and deposited two hundred Dollars in gold. One hundred and fifty of which I received at Philadelphia and fifty from my son at Boston—

7. VII.  Sleep till daylight relaxation from excessive stricture, otherwise no better than for the last six months Attended Public worship at Saint Johns Church 23d. Sunday after Trinity— Mr. Pyne preached from Phillippians 3.17. [“]Brethren be followers together of me and mark them which walk so, as ye have us for an ensample” and he administered the Communion after the Sermon, to the part of which, I did not stay— After dinner he preached from John 10.14. [“]I know my sheep.” from which words Mr. Pyne drew in irresistible conclusion of the Divinity of Jesus—but from which a very different conclusion might be drawn Mr. Pynes preaching always breeds in my mind an irresistible doubt whether he believes what he says. Evening visits from Mrs. Turnbull and her daughter Catherine, Mrs. Swift, Miss Abert daughter of Col Abert and Mr. Moody—

8. VII.  I awoke in time to hear the clock strike four. slept again rose about seven. warm and fine weather. My disability mental and bodily surpasses my power of expression and my conception—forgiveness and mercy is all that I can even pray for and in that spirit I must abide my time— Call at the Bank of the Metropolis drew one hundred dollars and paid to Mrs. John Adams for household expenses At the Franklin Insurance Company Office received four hundred and seventy five dollars in Virginia Bills the Dividend payable on the first of this month At the Bank of Washington received two hundred and twenty five dollars in Bills being the Dividends on Washington City Corporation six per cent stocks for the first of July and first of October 1847. At the National Intelligencer Office were I saw Joseph Gales and had some conversation with him— Received Eveg visits from Mr. Larned, Mary E. E. Cutts, Mr. Charles Gilpin of Philadelphia, and Mr. Allen the minister of the Unitarian Church.

9— VI.  Summer weather—slept till I heard the clock strike three—then slept again till daylight. The Journey from home appears to have left my health much in the state that it was there, the prospect of life continuing as from day to day— Call at Bank of the Metropolis, deposited from the Franklin Insurance Company four hundred and seventy five dollars, and from the Washington Bank of City Corporation Stock two hundred and twenty five dollars. Dr. Thomas. B. J. Frye was here this morning. I received a visit from J. Erving Duncan styling himself a Nephew of General Irvin the late Whig Candidate for the Office of Governor of Pennsylvania I enquired of Mr. Duncan if he had any particular object in paying me this visit—he said no, but I suppose him to be in search of some Office. I received visits also from Commodore Morris, Rev Smith Pyne, and Judge Wm. Cranch at whose house I called yesterday but he was then in attendance on his Court— I received a card from C. S. Whitney Doorkeeper of the House of Representatives. I suppose he means in expectancy I received also 21. Volumes of Documents of the last and preceeding Session of Congress. Ride after dinner till sunset. Isaac Hull Adams is employed in the Service of the Coast Survey

10. VI.  Brown the Barber comes to me every third day. I had a tolerable quiet night and am able to dress myself with some assistance from Mrs. Goods—and with that of my Grand Daughter Mary Louisa I resumed my Diary from the first of this month. took a long morning walk and visited Mrs. Madison with whom I found her niece Miss Anna Payne—both in good health. Enos Ray came with a Bill of $89.51 cents for keeping a pair of horses from the first of June to the first of November which I paid by Check on the Bank of Metropolis. No ride in the Carriage and no visitors this day.

11. VI.  A not very quiet night, nor so promising as those which have preceded it— I received visits from Phosius Kavasales stationed at the Navy Yard as Chaplain from Benjamin Ogle Tayloe, and his sister Miss Virginia Tayloe Dr. John. M. Thomas was here this Evening—very unwell—which has been the occasion of his not coming before. Cards from Mr. Clingman. I received a Letter from Elisha Whittlesey General Agent of the Board of Managers of the National Washington Monument Society enclosing copies of three Resolutions adopted at a meeting of the 2d. of this month of the Board of Managers. First that the Corner stone of the proposed Monument be laid on the 22d. of February next provided a suitable site can be obtained in time. Second that a Committee to consist of the mayor the first Vice President and the General Agent Whittlesey be appointed to apply to Congress early in the Session for a suitable site in the public mall for the proposed Monument and that the said Committee be requested to apply to the Hon John Quincy Adams to deliver an Address on the occasion of laying the Corner Stone. Third.
