That a Committee be appointed to make the necessary arrangements for the ceremony of laying the Corner Stone of the proposed Monument— I regret that I am physically disabled from performing the duty which I am requested to undertake by the extinction of my voice. Just before noon, I rode to the Astronomical Observatory where I found Lieut M. F. Maury and sundry other Officers and inspected the following Instruments. One the West Transit Instrument. 2. The Prime Vertical Transit Instrument. 3. The Mural Circle. 4. The Meridian Circle. 5. The Refraction Circle. received and mounted since I left this place last June— 6. The Equatorial. but none of them in a condition to take an Observation at mid day I called at Commodore Morris but he was not at home. The day was fine but cooler than it has been for several preceding days

12. VI.  As quiet a night as will ever fall to my lot hereafter. Morning visits from Col Haine and Ashbury Dickins Secretary of the Senate. Walk as far as the City  Dr. John M. Thomas was here and upon consultation gave me medical advice. He was here also in the evening on a friendly visit with his father. I had also a morning visit from Stephen Douglass now a Senator from the State of Illinois. I received a Letter from Aaron Leggett with a printed memorial from him to Congress stating his Claims upon Mexico—

13. VI.  Unquiet and half sleepless night. Morning visit from Dr. Todson. Received Littells Living Age No 183. My wife had a Letter from Mrs. C. F. Adams with a Bill of Lading for a box of merchandise by the schooner Harriet from Boston. The Letter mentions the unfortunate marriage of Miss Louisa Wales, to a man by the name of Kimball, who failed upon the day of his marriage. I called at the General Post Office. Cave Johnson the Post Master General was absent in Cabinet meeting at the President’s. I saw the 2nd. assistant Post master General B. F. Brown and left with him A Tillinghasts Letter on the location of the Post Office at West Wrentham. Walk home met Arthur Stansbury the Reporter, who walked home with me but did not come in. Afternoon ride till sunset.

14. VI.  Twenty-fourth Sunday after Trinity—heard Mr. Pyne in the morning from 2d Corinthians 7.10. For Godly sorrow worketh repentance to salvation not to be repented of. But the sorrow of the world worketh death And in the Afternoon from John 8.11. “Neither do I condemn thee go and sin no more.” After the Evening Service we took a short ride.

15— VI  An uncomfortable and restless night. Brother Paul and Brother Bernard Monks of the order of Saint Francis from the County of Galway Ireland came introduced by Mr. Joyce my neighbor and Mr.. They brought Certificates from W. Matthews Rector of St Patricks Church and James P. Donellan Rector of St Matthews Church in this City. They are making collections for the relief of the distressed in Ireland. I settled the account with Isaac Hull Adams for the expenses of the Journey from Quincy to Washington. first to the fifth of November 1847. amount of the expense One hundred and forty-two dollars and thirty cents. I gave a check to I. H. Adams for fifty seven dollars and thirty cents on the Bank of the Metropolis for the Balance due to him. I received a pamphlet of Observations on the Aboriginal Monuments of the Mississippi Valley by E. G. Squier. I called at the Navy Department to see the Secretary John. Y. Mason. But he had just gone over to the Presidents. Dr. Thomas was here and gave me medical advice. Evening visit from my neighbour Albert K. Parris second Comptroller of the Treasury.

16. VI.  I called at the Navy Department to see the Secretary of the Navy but he was in Cabinet Meeting at the President’s— I met in the street Lewis. C. Levin the native American Member from Philadelphia. at Coleman’s Hotel and left a Card for Stephen. A. Douglass Senator from the State of Illinois. I also met Lieut Maury and agreed to Call at the Observatory this Evening to view the moon through the Equatorial if the Sky should prove bright. At six oclock P.M. I went accordingly it being the ninth day of the Moon and the Sky sufficiently clear to look at the Moon, but thickning with haze till nothing distinct was to be seen and I came home before eight oclock. Lieut Maury promised to call on me the first clear Evening. But Astronomical Observation is always liable to disappointment from transient clouds— Lieut Maury told me that of seventeen Officers attached to the Observatory in 1846 scarcely one was now left but another set had taken their places. The appearance of the Moon as viewed through eye pieces of different magnifying power differs totally from its aspect to the naked eye. The appearance of the Disk resembles on its surface much to that of a plum Cake crusted with sugar. with great and extraordinary irregularities on the surface and several seeming holes going into impenetrable darkness. There is nothing resembling water and nothing having an appearance of vegetation, the general impression that it gives is of lifeless barrenness—the question whether it has any atmosphere remains unsettled. Mrs. Maury and several ladies and gentlemen came in as I came away. Mr. Maury spoke of Prof Pierce’s questions whether the Planet Neptune is really the Planet discovered by the previous calculations of Leverrier Its Orbit is not yet ascertained though inferred by approximation from the fact ascertained by Mr. Sears. J. Walker that the star was observed by the French Astronomer Lalande on the 8th. of May 1795. Three additional Planets named Astria, Hebe, and Iris have been discovered within the last two years— They are parts of that supposed exploded Planet between Mars and Jupiter of which four had been previously discovered and called Asteroids. Mr. Maury supposes that there are perhaps many more fragments of this Planet to be discovered hereafter.

17. VI.  A man by the name of William M. Thomas with a Commission as Acting Boatswain in the Navy and another as Prize master of a Mexican Vessel came with his papers and requested my assistance in support of his Claims in the Navy Department. I called accordingly at the Department but the Secretary was in Cabinet Meeting at the President’s. I rode to the Capitol and took out of the Congress Library an Edition of Pliny’s Letters and The Panegyric of Trajan with a French translation by De sassis. No English Translation of the Panegyric here. I took out also the second Volume of the English translation of Plato, by Floyer Sydenham and Thomas Taylor. in five Volumes Quarto. I took the second for the Timeus. I met at the House Mr. George. P. Marsh Member from the State of Vermont. Marked the time by the Dial of the House. I asked Mr. Marsh what was the meaning of the Dog days, as noted in our Common Almanacs, & said I considered their statements as impositions. He referred me to the Conversation Lexicon—which like all other Almanac statement of the Dog Days is false— I received a Letter from Col A. P. Hayne with a printed pamphlet being a Brief Sketch of his Life and Military Services.

18. VI.  I called this morning at the Navy Department and saw the Secretary John. Y. Mason. I spoke to him of the Claim of Wm. M. Thomas whose Papers I left with him. to which he promised to pay immediate attention. I spoke to him also of the Astronomical Observatory and of my earnest desire that an Appropriation may be made at the approaching Session of Congress for the annual composition and publication of an Nautical Almanac like that published in England and like the Connaissance des Temps Annually published in France. He read to me an extract of his Report to the President of the last year in which an appropriation was recommended for the publication of a Nautical Almanac which was accordingly proposed in the estimates of the Navy Department but which was accordingly proposed in the estimates of the Navy Department but which was struck out by the House He said he should renew the recommendation of the appropriation in the estimates for the approaching Session of Congress. Mr. Mason gave me also a Copy of his Address before the Alumni Association of the University of North Carolina. Delivered in Gerard Hall on the 2nd. of June last. the Evening before their Commencement Day. My wife dined at her sister Mrs. Fryes. The day was fair and the sky bright until the Evening. I intended to have paid another visit to the Observatory but as night came on the sky clouded up and after calling at Mr. Fryes, I returned home. postponing the visit to the Observatory. I returned the visit of Col Hayne by card left at his lodgings at Mrs. Ulrichs. I read something of the Panegyric of Trajan, and something of Taylor’s Translation of the Timeus of Plato—

19. VI.  Called at the Navy Department and left with the Secretary a charge of W. M. Thomas against the Government for two months service $50—which I had yesterday inadvertently left upon my table when I took his other papers to the Department— An orphan boy thirteen or fourteen years of age came with certificates of recommendation from James F Donellan Director of St Matthews Church—and N. Callen to procure for the boy whom they name Joseph J. Head employment— What he himself wants is to be appointed a Page in the House of Representatives. he says his name is Joseph Hill that his father was a Baptist minister who has been dead these five years and his mother died long before—that his present employment is to carry round the Baltimore Clipper for distributing which he pays the Publisher weekly and he pays two dollars a week for his board— I told him I would help him to get the appointment of a Page if I could, and bade him come to me again next Wednesday General Jesup and two of his daughters Lucy Ann and Jane paid us an evening visit. I answered Col Arthur. P. Hayne’s Letter thanking him for the present of his Autobiography

20. VI.  Beautiful weather but no abatement of my complaints my weakness increases— Wm. M Thomas was here but the Secretary of the Navy has not yet decided on his claims for arrears of payment and for appointment as Boatswain in the Navy—he is impatient to go to his family in Baltimore. I rode to the Capitol and walked home— I met at the Post Office of H.R.U.S. Robert Barnwell Rhett of South Carolina who was courteous and civil. B. B. French had gone to the Penitentiary, took a pen knife—compared my watch with the dial. My Sonnet was taken away last Winter— Walking home I met Arthur Stansbury the Reporter and John. W. Davis of Indiana Speaker of H.R.U.S. at the last or 29th. Congress. Not a member of the 30th. Congress. He told me he lodged where he always had at Mr. Leonard Harbaugh’s in eighth Street. After dinner ride with my Wife and Mary and then I went alone to the Observatory. Viewed through the Equatorial with Lieut Maury and Professor Hubbard the full moon, the planets Neptune, Iris, Mars and Saturn with his ring and one satellite. Viewed also through the west Transit Instrument the Transit of two Stars— Lieut Maury told me he was writing me a long Letter and he would soon invite me to look at the Nebulae in Orion. I came home about 8. oclock. Visit from Charles. B. King the Painter.

21. VI.  Eruption round my right knee I went with Isaac Hull Adams to the Unitarian Church where Mr. Allen preached from Matthew 24.14. “And this Gospel of the Kingdom shall be preached in all the World, for a witness unto all nations, and then shall the end come.” A very excellent Discourse characterizing with discrimination the peculiarity of the unpremeditated words of Christ with his confident assurance that Heaven and Earth shall pass away but that his word should not pass away— I walked home, and in the afternoon attended at St John’s Church where Mr. Pyne read the Evening Service for the 25th. Sunday after Trinity and preached from Revelation 3.18. I counsel thee, to buy of me gold tried in the fire that thou mayest be rich. The subject of the Discourse was the close of the Ecclesiastical year and the approaching commencement of a new year. The next Sunday being the first Sunday of Advent. It was of course a common place of lamentation over the past and earnest exhortation for the future— Notice was given of Thanksgiving next Thursday and a collection to be taken up.

22. VI.  Heard the Clock strike four A.M. Thomas Duckett a negro soliciting contributions to purchase his freedom and that of his family. Also for another family. B. B. French Clerk of the House of Representatives and C. S. Whitney Door Keeper of the House of Representatives were here. He told me there was one vacancy in the list of the Pages of the House and he would appoint Joseph Hill to fill it. but it must depend upon the Door Keeper who may be elected at the meeting of the House to confirm or annul the appointment— I returned the visit of Mr. John. W. Davis by leaving a card at his lodgings at Leonard Harbaugh’s. Evening visits from Lieut Whipple and Richard. D. Cutts. I received a Letter from John. P. Kennedy recommending Mr. Williams for the Office of Sergeant at Arms— My wife had a bad fall this day and hurt her face which almost crazed me I took a ride this afternoon. Miss Mary Hayne and her brother A. B. Hayne were here.

23. VI.  Succession of visitors. Among the rest two from Virginia named Cleighton and Robinson. Cleighton came to solicit my vote for his Father as Keeper of the Post Office of H.R.U.S. Also two Quakers or Friends one named David Adams from Madison County N.Y. the other Lewis from Pennsylvania. David Adams was very inquisitive of Genealogy and spoke of four Generations of his own name ending in Connecticut and New York but not of the Henry Adams race. Mary Louisa went as a Bridesmaid to the wedding of Miss Juliana Randall.

24. VI.  Warm rain night and morning. I received yesterday an invitation from Messrs. Willard to the opening Dinner of the City Hotel this day at 4. P.M. I have an invitation from S. Draper junr. Charles A Peabody, John Thomas, B. W. Binney, and L. B. Winard, a Committee of the New England Society of the City of New York to the dinner at the Astor House on the 22d. of December next, which I am to decline— A Letter from E. C. Wines of Burlington New Jersey about a normal School for that State and my opinion is asked upon this subject— Letter from G. V. Washington Georgetown 22d. Novr. 1847, declaring himself a Candidate for the appointment of Sergeant at Arms. of H.R.U.S— and an invitation from Col J. J. Abert for Saturday Evening at six oclock.— I called at Colemans Hotel to see Mrs. George Barkman and her Son and daughter but they had left the City day before yesterday in the Steamer for Richmond Virginia Mary Louisa dined with the Bridal Party at Mr. Thomas Munroe’s.

25. VI.  Thanksgiving Day— At the Unitarian Church Mr. Allen preached a Sermon of Thanksgiving for the enjoyment of blessings National and Individual, but he touched upon no Political topic and he delivered his text in so low a tone of voice that I did not hear whence it was taken—but its reference was to the Land flowing with milk and honey. We had visits from Col Arthur. P. Hayne, and Mrs. Hayne. Dr. Thomas was also here and prescribed for my wife who is suffering from her fall, and for me. He spoke to me also of an Article in the Baltimore Sun Newspaper of Tuesday last attributing to me certain opinions respecting the War and prospects of Peace with Mexico— I received a Circular Letter from the President of Harvard University Edward Everett inviting me as one of the Subscribers to the Fund for the purchase of the large Telescope, which has recently been resumed at Cambridge to visit the Observatory with any members of my family on Monday Evening the 20th. of December or should the Evening prove unfavorable on the first clear Evening of the week preceding any full moon. Mrs. John Adams and her daughter Mary Louisa spent the Evening at Mrs. Randalls—

26. VI—  Morning walk round 4 1/2 Street Church. I met Thomas. L. Clingman a Whig member from the State of North Carolina of the 28th. Congress who lost his election in the 29th. and is now returned again a member elect of the 30th. I met also Sargent of Philadelphia— I had received a Letter from him soliciting my vote for him as Clerk of the House. I told him I should be glad to vote for him, but my vote was pledged. He thought circumstances might occur to modify my intentions, to which I assented but said that I never had approved the principle of turning out a competent incumbent of public Officers to substitute another on Party Principles— He said he knew that but French himself had acted upon other principles— I told him I understood Mr. French had been misrepresented on this subject—which French told me himself, and that he had been charged with dismissing Officers whom he had on the contrary, labored assiduously to retain. It is however very apparent that this election of all the Officers of the House will be carried by the screws of the Whig Party. I suppose they will be applied for Matthew St. Clair Clarke and there is little chance therefore for Mr. Sargent. He walked with me to the door of my house, but declined to come in. I took a ride with my wife and Grand Daughter this Evening. We had no visitors— I received a Letter from G. W. Hill of Ashland Ohio full of political speculations to which he requests my answer. I began but did not finish a Letter to Elisha Whittlesey General agent of the Board of Managers of the National Monument Society.

27. VI.  I told Miss Stafford that Mr. Palfrey was a member elect of the 30th. Congress and that she would do well to apply to him for assistance in support of her claims if as I hoped he should be here at the opening of the Session, which I was sorry to say was very doubtful, as I am informed he was very ill a few days since. Morning walk round 4 1/2 Street. Evening Party of men at Col. J. J. Abert’s I went at half past seven and came home about nine oclock before supper— Mary Louisa spent the Evening at Mrs. Randall’s—

28. VI.  At the Unitarian Church in the morning Mr. Allen preached from John 3.11. “Verily verily I say unto thee we speak that we do know and testify that we have seen.[”] At St. Johns Church it was Advent Sunday my wife went and took the Communion. There was no Sermon after Dinner there but catechizing the children— In the Evening at 7 oclock I went again to the Unitarian Church where Mr. Allen preached from Matthew 6.25 “Therefore I say unto you take no thought for your life what ye shall eat or what ye shall drink, nor yet for your body what ye shall put on. is not the life more than meat, and the body than raiment.”— Isaac Hull Adams went with me and we came home about nine o’clock.

29. VI.  A night mare in morning sleep I called at the Office of Stephen Pleasanton the Fifth Auditor with a Letter from Wm. B. Duggan of Quincy in behalf of Capt Charles Swift for the appointment of Keeper of the Light House on Minotts Ledge at the Cohasset Rocks. The recommendation had been sent to the Secretary of the Treasury the 23d. of October. Mr. Pleasanton referred me to Mr. McGinnis at the Treasury Department— The Secretary Mr. Walker was at the Presidents. Mr. McGinnis said the recommendations would be laid before him for his consideration. Ride to the Capitol where I compared my Chronometer with the Dial of H.R.U.S. and lost my glove. In the Evening we had a visit from Mr. John. A. Rockwell member elect for H.R.U.S from State of Connecticut. He arrived here this morning— Mary Louisa went to the Railway Depot expecting the arrival of her friend Louise Agniel with Mr. Schenck member of H.R.U.S. from Ohio, but they did not come

30. VI.  I have very indifferent nights but not entirely without sleep, and I have now visits more numerous than I can recollect or recall, chiefly from Members of Congress arriving from day to day, from Candidates for the Offices to be elected by the House of Representatives and from mendicants of all descriptions, some for money, some for place, and not a few for both. This day I had a visit from Mr. Otho. H. Williams candidate for the Office of Sergeant at Arms of the House, in whose favor I had already received a Letter from my friend John. P. Kennedy, and I received this day a printed recommendation of W. W. Seaton the mayor of the City and five others, and a statement by himself that he is the Son of James Moorhead of Indiana, Pennsylvania who was removed from Office in this City by R. J. Walker This recommendation was for the Office of Sergeant at Arms— I rode to the Capitol, and enquired in the Clerk’s Office of the House if I had left my glove there, but did not find it— I walked home which was almost as much as I could perform. Mr. Archibald Campbell and his wife spent part of the Evening here. He is the Chief Clerk of the Secretary of War W. L. Marcy

1— VI.  I received a printed recommendation signed by W. W. Seaton Mayor of the City and seven others of Joshua L Henshaw as a Candidate for Door Keeper of the House of Representatives and Wm. Whitney an inhabitant of this City where he says he has resided these five and twenty years, came in person to solicit my vote for himself as Door Keeper of the House of Representatives he being no relation to C. S Whitney the present Door Keeper who is the son of the late Reuben M. Whitney— Joseph Hill the Orphan boy whom I had recommended for the appointment of a Page to the House, was here again with his recommendation from Mr. Donellan Director of St Matthews Church and Mr. N. Callan to which the present Door Keeper C. S. Whitney desired that I would add my recommendation in writing which I did, but told him that he must go to Mr. Donelan and get his assent to the rectification of his name which the boy had made himself. Mr. John Mason junr. Son of General John Mason formerly of Georgetown but now of Virginia was here and I mistook him for his brother James Mason now a Senator from the State of Virginia. I had visits also from Mr. Foster a member of the House and Mr. Thompson member elect from Indiana— Col Kearney came with Mr. Mason who introduced him to me, though he had already been introduced by Col Abert— Theodore Talbot spent the Evening here.

2. VI.  Birth day of my Granddaughter Mary Louisa Adams who enters on her twentieth year. Joseph Grinnell arrived here yesterday and visited us with Robert. C. Winthrop this morning— Robert C. Dyson a boy about 12 years of age brought me a note from Mrs. Colvin his aunt, soliciting my influence to obtain for him the appointment of a Page to the House of Representatives. I desired him to say to Mrs. Colvin that I should be glad if he could succeed in his desire but I had already recommended one and could not expect that my influence would have no weight for more than one— I would name him to the Doorkeeper, but he would do well to apply for the influence of Members possessing more than mine. Mrs. Shryock a widow solicits employment in the Folding Room of the H.R.U.S. for her son Samuel Shryock sixteen years old, who has lost his father— She does not apply for his appointment as a Page, for which she supposes him to be too old. The Pages being generally between seven and fourteen. Mr. James Buchanan Secretary of State our next door neighbour spent the evening with us—

3. VI.  Awake and heard the clock strike two then slept till the clock struck five, lay awake till Seven then I rose. Returned the visit of Mr. Grinnell at Willards City Hotel and that of Mr. Winthrop at Coleman’s— Miss Louise Agniel arrived in company with Mr. Robert C. Schenck. Evening visit from General Dix member of the Senate from the State of New York.

4. VI  A multitude of visitors. Some members of Congress others Candidates for Offices to be elected at the organization of Congress and especially of the House of Representatives next Monday. I went to the House of Representatives expecting to meet there some member of the Massachusett Delegation to give him the Letter that I received from Mr. John. P. Kennedy recommending Mr. Otho. H. Williams for the Office of Sergeant at Arms of the House, that might be presented this Evening at the Whig Caucus of members, of the House which Mr. Williams had requested I would do, but I met no Member from Massachusetts at the House and was thus unable to comply with the request— Mr. Fendall was here in the Evening.

5— VI.  At the Unitarian Church this morning Mr. Allen preached from 2 Timothy 2.22. [“]Follow righteousness, faith, charity, peace with them that call on the Lord out of a pure heart.” the argument of the Discourse was that the test of a true Christian was righteousness, sincerity and purity of heart. In the Afternoon at St John’s Church Mr. Pyne preached and read the Evening Service for the second Sunday in Advent and preached from Proverbs 15.8. “The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination to the Lord; but the prayer of the upright is his delight.” I went again to the Unitarian Church in the Evening when Mr. Allen preached from Galatians 6.7. “Be not deceived God is not mocked; for whatsoever a man soweth, that shall he also reap”— Miss Agniel and Mary Louisa went with me to Church and we met there Mr. Robert. C. Schenck— He told me that the Caucus of last Evening had in the first instance nominated Mr. Samuel. F. Vinton as Candidate for Speaker but he had declined and they had then unanimously nominated Robert. C. Winthrop and they had also with equal unanimity agreed to nominate all the subordinate Officers to be elected by the House. Mrs. George Graham called this morning to invite us to the Wedding of her daughter Miss Graham.

6. VI.  Commencement of the First Session of the 30th. Congress. At the first vote for the choice of Speaker of the House the whole number of votes was 220. of which Robert. C. Winthrop of Massachusetts had 108. At the second vote the whole number was 219. of which Winthrop had 109. At the third vote the whole number was 118. of which Winthrop at 110. and was chosen. The Oath of Office was administered to him by me and then the same Oath was administered to all the members elect by him— My wife was taken very ill this evening and Dr. Thomas was sent for and assured me that it would not be of serious consequences. It was the effect of extraordinary agitation—with which my own health deeply sympathized.

7. VI.  Mr. Lewis C. Levin a Native American Member from Philadelphia had moved yesterday, that Benjamin B. French the Clerk of the House for the last Congress should be appointed the Clerk for the present Congress. At the last Congress he was so appointed without opposition. This morning Mr. Levin modified his resolution to read “that this House do now proceed to vote viva voce for Clerk”—which was done. Mr. Toombs of Georgia nominated Thomas Jefferson Campbell of Tennessee. Mr. Broadhead nominated Benjamin B. French. Mr. Holmes of South Carolina nominated Samuel L. Gouverneur— The whole number of votes given was 225. necessary to a choice 113. which number was received by Thomas J. Campbell. French received 109. Gouverneur 1. George Kent 1. Mr. Tuck from New Hampshire and Nathan Sergeant 1. Mr. Giddings of Ohio— I voted myself for French having promised him some months since so to do— Several Whigs, a number sufficient to have elected him, had made him the same promise, unless overpowered by the Caucus screw—which was actually applied to them— Campbell was a Member of the 28th. Congress from Tennessee— A resolution was next offered by Alex Evans of Maryland to draw lots for the choice of choice of seats—which was done. The names of all the Members being put by the Clerk into a box and as each members name was drawn from the box, he selected and took his seat for the Session. My name was early drawn and I took the same seat which I have occupied for the last ten years, no other member having manifested the disposition even to take it—though certainly one of the best seats in the House. Washington Hunt one of the joint Committee on the part of the House to wait on the President and inform him that a Quorum of both Houses had been formed and were ready to receive from him any communication he was pleased to make reported that the President would immediately transmit a Message in writing. It was accordingly immediately presented and read occupying nearly three hours in the reading and the usual resolutions for printing a number of copies, with and without accompanying Documents, were passed— A resolution was passed for fixing the daily hour of meeting of the House, at twelve oclock noon, till farther order— Some debate concerning the Committee for revision of the Rules and a motion to strike out what is called the hour rule, was left undecided— The House adjourned about 4. oclock— My wife was confined by indisposition to her bed all day, but was recovering. Evening visit from Mr. Glück.

8. VI.  Clingman had moved yesterday to lay upon the Table of Henly to reconsider the vote adopting the Rules of the last Congress, excepting the one hour— Clingman withdrew his motion this morning to lay it upon the Table; and the motion to reconsider has passed over until the third Monday in this month, before which the Committee on the revision of the Rules, are to report Their names have not yet been published in the Intelligencer and I know not who they are— The organization of the House was completed by the choice of Officers—Nathan Sargeant was elected Sergeant At Arms by 116 votes out of 224. Newton Lane the Sergeant at Arms of the last Congress had 96 votes and Charles A. Whitney 12. The next election was of Door Keeper for which Robert. E. Horner received 117. votes and Cornelius. S. Whitney the Door keeper of the last Congress had 107. The last election was of Post Master for which John. M. Johnson the present Post master received 111 votes out of 221. and Wm. J Mc.Cormick 110. Johnson is thus the only officer of the Administration Party re-elected in opposition to the Whig Caucus Candidate— All the Officers have been elected by majorities of one or two votes. My wife was better this day and Dr. Thomas visited us twice.

9. VI.  Morning visit from Dr. Thomas. at eleven oclock I attended at the House. At the meeting of the House Timothy Pillsbury appeared and took a seat as member from Texas. Jameson of Missouri moved that when the House should adjourn it should be over to Monday to give the Speaker time to appoint the standing Committees, which was agreed to— A Resolution moved by Mr. Collamer of Vermont for the appointment of a Joint Committee on the Library— Brodhead gave notice that he would ask leave to introduce a Bill relating to the Postage of newspapers— Pollock of Pennsylvania offered a Resolution for the appointment of two Chaplains one by each House and of different Denominations, against which John Pettit of Indiana made his usual Speech. He offered two Amendments to the Resolution, one to strike out the different Denominations and the other to add, that they should be paid by the members out of their own money—He disputes the Constitutional power to pay for Religious Services out of the Public Treasury—but he could neither get the yeas or nays, nor any vote besides his own to either of his Amendments— Pollocks resolution was adopted nemine contra disente—except Pettit, there were no small number of other members not voting at all. Henley of Indiana moved the appointment of the standing Committees— Samuel F. Vinton of Ohio moved a series of Resolutions for dividing the Committee of Commerce into two, one for Foreign Commerce and the other Commerce between the States, which immediately gave rise to Debate— In the midst of which I left the House about one oclock to attend with the ladies of our family at the wedding of Miss Jennie Graham daughter of the late George Graham a school companion of my Grand Daughter Mary Louisa— We got to the house just as the Nuptial Ceremony had been performed by the Rev Mr. Pyne— There was a numerous Company present and plenteous cold collation—from which we retired about two oclock

10. VI.  The House adjourned yesterday over to Monday. I had this day several visitors, among whom John P. Hale, senator from New Hampshire George Ashmun member of the House from Massachusetts Truman Smith member from Connecticut, Thomas Clingman member from North Carolina in the morning. Lieut. N. F. Maury Superintendent of the Observatory, the Roman Catholic Bishop of New York Hughes with Mr. Robinson the Reporter of the New York Tribune newspaper— I had received a long Letter from Lieut Maury dated at the National Observatory 17th. Novr. 1847 upon the subject of Astronomy and of the Instruments in use at the Observatory— Bishop Hughes has been called here by the Executive Government to be consulted respecting negotiations with Mexico relating to Religion— In company with him is Bishop Walsh residing at Halifax. I had no conversation with Bishop Hughes concerning the object of his visit here, but Mr. Robinson has taken pains to circulate a subscription among the members of the House of Representatives, requesting Mr. Hughes to preach in the Hall of the House of Representatives, next Sunday morning— I subscribed my name to this request, to which the Bishop has assented

11. VI.  I returned this morning several visits that of Mr. J A Rockwell at Coleman’s but he was not at his lodgings—that of Mr. Hilliard of Alabama who was also absent, and that of Mr. Thomas Clingman of North Carolina with whom I sat and conversed for some time As my carriage stopt at the door of his lodgings Mr. Mangum the Senator from North Carolina came out, and stopped and spoke to me as I was seated in the Carriage— I went also to the House of Representatives Clerks Office before returning home. I received a Tragedy of five Acts called Arnold or the Treason of West point by Horatio Hubbel printed at Philadelphia, in the present year 1847. The copy of it sent to me is addressed to me in manuscript, but without the signature of the author or indicating from whom it comes— It is Dedicated to the American People as a fragment of their History— As a Drama it is constructed according to the rules of art composed in blank verse, but without anything in it, in my opinion worthy to be remembered. I do not know that it would be possible to compose a Tragedy upon that subject which could remain as a work for a duration of Ages. It is perhaps the most extraordinary incident of the American Revolution and as a part of its History possesses deep interest—the History of it as a narrative has been written and published in French by B. De Marbois who was a man of Letters, and Secretary of the Minister of France, the Chevalier De La Luzerne in company with whom I came in the Summer of 1779. from L’Orient to Boston in the French Frigate La Sensible This work of Marbois is exceedingly well written, in a style studied to resemble that of Salust in his History with the War with Jugurtha. The subject has been very indifferently treated by all the English and American Historians of the Revolution and not remarkably well by the Italian Botan I believe this subject susceptible of a great Historical work, but doubt whether it will ever find a writer equal to it—

12. VI  At eleven oclock this morning I attended in company with Miss Agniel, my Grand Daughter Mary Louisa and Isaac Hull, at the Hall of the House of Representatives where the Roman Catholic Bishop of New York, an Irishman by the name of Hughes performed Divine Service. He was the second Roman Catholic Bishop, native of Ireland whom I had heard preach in that Hall. he was arrayed in his episcopal garments but so simplified as scarcely to be distinguished from a simple Clergymans gown. He began the Service by stating the substance of a prayer taken from the Mass Book, and embracing the objects of most of the Prayers in the Book of the Church of England, a prayer of blessing upon the race of man in general, and upon the several Classes of men including the President of the United States Magistrates, and the people of all Classes and Denominations— He then read from the 20th. Chapter of St Mathews from the 20th. to the 28th. verse.

13. VI.  At the House the appointment of the standing Committees was announced. Samuel F Vinton is Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, John A. Rockwell of Connecticut of the Committee of Claims, Washington Hunt of New York, of the Committee of Commerce, Jacob Collamer of Vermont, of the Public Lands, William L Goggin of Virginia, of the Post Offices and Post Roads, John G. Chapman of Maryland, of the District of Columbia, Joseph. R. Ingersoll of Pennsylvania, on the Judiciary, and Daniel. P. King of Massachusetts, on Revolutionary Claims, Andrew Stuart of Pennsylvania of Manufactures, Hugh White of New York, of Agriculture, andP. Gentry of Tennessee, of Indian Affairs, John M Botts of Virginia, Military Affairs, Thomas. B. King of Georgia on Naval Affairs, Truman Smith of Connecticut of Foreign Affairs, and C. B. Smith of Indiana on the Territories, All the Chairmen, of the standing Committees are whigs—of the Speakers creed and he has made me Chairman of the Joint Library Committee on the part of the House, with Wm. B. Preston of Virginia and Henry. C. Murphy of New York. The whigs not of the Speakers School, are all placed, in the most insignificant positions on the Committees. an arrangement which has given much dissatisfaction. There was scarcely any transaction of business, the House having received very early in the day a message from the Senate announcing the decease of Jabez. W. Huntington Senator from Connecticut who died after a short illness at his residence in Norwich on the 2d. day of November last. upon which Mr. John. A. Rockwell, made the usual obituary Eulogium, and offered the usual resolutions, adopted on such occasions, concluding with one that the House do adjourn, which was accordingly done— Of all the existing members of the Senate, Mr. Huntington was the one with whom I most thoroughly sympathized in sentiment, and I consider his loss, as a grievous misfortune to the Country— His successor appointed by the Governor of Conn during the recess of the Legislature, of that State, is Mr. Roger S. Baldwin, who was my associate in the Trial before the Supreme Court, in the case of the negroes, of the Schooner Amistad.

14. VII.  At the opening of the Session of the House this morning Joshua. R. Giddings of Ohio requested the attention of the House to an attack, in the Public Press upon him, in a newspaper called the Daily National Whig on account of his vote for Speaker—and he sent the paper to the Clerk with the Article entitled Party treachery against Giddings, Tuck, Palfrey. Et id genus omne. The article was very abusive, threatening to exhibit a full statement of the course of those Whigs who deserted their Party on the occasion of the election of their Officers of the House, and to send two thousand copies of the National Whig in which it appears, into each of the Districts of those gentlemen in order that their Constituencies may be made acquainted with the facts in the case— Giddings stated that this Paper was established professing to be for the purpose of promoting the election of General Taylor, that the Editor not avowing himself was one of John Tyler’s appointments and was said to be connected with certain members of the House— Mr. Giddings in a summary manner justified himself for his votes, and disclaimed any intention to implicate the Whig Party in this infamous attempt to brow beat and intimidate the members of the Party. No reply was made, but it was manifest that this was the purpose of the establishment of the Daily National Whig— When I first came to the City, a man came to me proposing to me to subscribe for this Paper. I asked him who was to be its Editor, which he declined to answer, and I accordingly declined to subscribe for it. Whether the Speaker has any concern in the establishment of the Paper is not fully established. Charles. J. Ingersoll, made a Report in part from the Select Committee of the Revisal of the Rules, which was made the special order for Thursday next— A Memorial from James Munroe of the City of New York was presented contesting the election of David S. Jackson the sitting member— A Chaplain, for the present Session was elected. Mr. Levin nominated the Rev R. W. Cushman, Baptist, Mr. Ashmun nominated the Rev Orville Dewey Congregationalist I nominated the Rev. R. R. Gurley. Mr. McLean nominated the Rev J. M. McJilton Protestant Episcopalian Mr. Staunton nominated Rev Levi R. Reese, Methodist John Pettit of Indiana, and Wm. Sawyer of Ohio were excused from voting. At the third trial Mr. Gurley received 102 votes and Mr. Cushman 100. Gurley was therefore elected as the Chaplain of the House for the present Session— The House adjourned before three o’clock. And last Evening the information was received of the decease at New York of the late Chancellor Kent.

15. VI.  In the Senate this morning John C. Calhoun, offered two Resolutions against the conquest of Mexico either to hold it as a Province or to incorporate it in the Union and that no line of policy in the further prosecution of the War, should be adopted which may lead to consequences so disastrous— To be discussed hereafter. In the House Mr. Vinton’s proposition to establish an additional standing Committee in Internal Commerce between the States was fiercely contested by Robert. B. Rhett of South Carolina, and debated by several others. A message was received from the President assigning his reasons for what is called the pocket veto. This Bill being an Act to provide for the continuing certain works in the Territory of Wisconsin, and for other purposes past the two Houses of Congress, and was presented to the President on the last day of the last Session. He neither signed, nor returned it. in consequence of which it failed to become a Law— This message contained his reasons for not signing the Bill. A debate ensued, upon what was to be done with the message which was not ultimately decided— Isaac. E. Holmes of Charleston South Carolina, offered Resolutions similar to those presented by Mr. Calhoun, to the Senate.

16. VI.  In the SenateFoot, one of the Senators from the state of Mississippi announced the decease of his Colleague Jesse Speight who died at his residence in Mississippi on the first day of May last. I had known him from the year 1829. to 1837. as a member of the House of Representatives from the state of North Carolina In the latter year he removed to Mississippi and was immediately and successively elected to both Houses of the Legislature of that State, and then to the Senate of the United States— He appears to have been of a remarkably attractive personal character of which however he exhibited no evidence in Public life. The usual Obituary Resolutions including that of immediate adjournment were passed in the Senate and announced to the House— There the special order of the day was the consideration of the Report of the Select Committee to revise the Rules and Orders of the House—which report like those of all similar Committees which I have known since I became a member of the House, are exemplifications of that state described in Paradise Lost where [“]chaos umpire sits, and by decision more embroils the fray”— The special order was postponed till tomorrow at the motion of Charles. J. Ingersoll. The debate upon the message of the President received yesterday assigning his reasons for withholding his assent to the River and Harbour Bill. of the last Session, was resumed, and Schenck of Ohio and John Pettit of Indiana made speeches against it. Before Pettit concluded the message from the Senate was received announcing the decease of Jesse Speight—whereupon Jacob Thompson of Mississippi made an Eulogistic speech concluding with the usual Resolutions, including by the immediate adjournment of the House.

17. VI.  The Senate adjourned yesterday over till next Monday. At the House the special order of the day was again postponed—and John Pettit of Indiana made a personal explanation, charging with falsehood the Report in the Union newspaper of Pettit’s speech made yesterday— Mr. Botts of Virginia introduced a Joint Resolution, authorizing the Postmaster General to renew his engagement with certain Virginia Rail Roads. Mr. Meade of Virginia announced the decease of George C. Dromgoole late and long a member of this House, who died on the 27th. of April last at his residence in the County of Brunswick a few days after he had received intelligence of his re-election to Congress. Mr. Meade pronounced his Eulogy, which he estimated at a high but very indulgent standard He concluded with the usual resolutions and the House adjourned.

18. VI.  In the House the Report of the Select Committee for the revisal of the Rules was the Special Order for debate and the usual effect of the appointment of such Committees was again exemplified that is to say it only made the subject of the rules more complicated than it was The first discussion was about what is called the hour Rule, that is the limitation of an hour for the time allowed to every member to speak upon any subject in Debate. The select Committee first proposed an extent of the limitation from an hour to an hour and a half, and secondly they proposed a substitute for the hour Rule allowing each member who proposes any measure another hour to close the Debate which of course establishes an inequality between the members some to be indulged with two hours and others to be confined to one. This introduced a long Debate, which was closed by a re adoption of the hour rule with the proviso that in closing debates every member shall be allowed five minutes to explain in Committee of the whole any Amendment he may offer—and by adopting a further Rule that members may address the House from the Clerks Desk or from a place near the Speakers Chair instead of from his own Seat. An additional Rule was adopted that except during the last ten days of the Session the Speaker shall not entertain a motion to suspend the Rules of the House except on Monday of every week, and except a motion for going into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union. Another Rule proposed was that when the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, or a Committee of the whole House finds itself without a Quorum, the Chairman shall cause the Role of the House to be called, and thereupon the Committee shall rise and the Chairman shall Report the names of the absentees which shall be entered in the Journal— Other Rules were proposed and among the rest one that in addition to the other standing Committees of the House there shall be one called the Smithsonian Committee whose duty it shall be to superintend the affairs of the Smithsonian Institution. This again introduced a long Debate all which was closed by a Resolution offered by Charles. J. Ingersoll that the Rules of the House at the last Congress with the modifications of them, this day adopted be henceforth the Rules and regulations of this House during this Session of Congress. And so ends the undertaking to simplyfy and improve the Rules for this time— The House adjourned about three oclock.

19. VI.  I attended Public Worship this morning in the Hall of the House of Representatives where the Chaplain of the House Mr. Gurley preached from John 1.16. “And of his fulness have all we received and grace for grace. 17. For the Law was given by Moses, but grace and truth came by Jesus Christ”— And in the Afternoon at Saint Johns.

20 VI  In the House the Speaker called this morning for Petitions. I presented a Petition ofpraying for Peace with Mexico and moved its reference to a Select Committee Lynn Boyd moved its reference to the Committee of Foreign Affairs. Lynn Boyd modified his motion to be referred to the Committee on Military Affairs. it was finally referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs— I presented also the petition of Photius Kavasales. praying he might be authorized to change his name to that of Fisk. which was contested and laid over under the Rule. I presented also the Petitions of John Mitchell for a Pension, referred to the Committee on Invalid Pension, and of John. P. Andrews of Salem for Peace with Mexico, referred to the Committee of Foreign Affairs. A great number of Petitions were presented and numerous Resolutions were offered, one by one that the same number of Pages be employed for the use of the House, that were employed previous to the 27th. Congress to wit 12. I offered this Resolution at the request of the Door Keeper Mr. Horner and it was adopted without opposition— Isaac E. Holmes moved a Resolution that the monies deposited with the several States and Territories as a Loan from the Treasury of the Surplus Revenue being now called for, by the Government of the United States, before resort being had to another Loan. It was referred to the Committee of Ways and Means. Thomas Butler King moved that it shall be the duty of the Speaker to remove the Desks from the Hall and that a large table be placed in front of the Clerks Desk for the use of the members. This was an imitation of the English House of Commons—but the Resolution was laid on the Table. Gentry moved a request to the President to communicate to the House the instructions given to John Slidell as minister Plenipotentiary and Embassador Extraordinary to the Government of Mexico. Schenck moved a long Resolution of enquiry for copies of all orders and communications with the Government of New Mexico— John Pettit moved two Resolutions of the right of Congress to make internal improvements for purposes of War and Navigation— He moved the Previous Question. Simms of South Carolina moved to lay them both on the Table— Charles. J. Ingersoll called for a division of the Question, to take separate votes on laying each Resolution on the Table. Pettit claimed it was not in order to separate them— The Speaker decided that the Question was divisible and might be taken separately on each Question From this decision Simms of South Carolina appealed, and the decision was reversed by Tellers 63 to 87. The Question of laying both the Resolutions on the Table was rejected by yeas and nays 70. to 124. The Previous Question was not seconded, Howell Cobb of Georgia declared his intention, to Debate, the Resolutions and they were laid over, under the Rule— Wm. A. Richardson of Illinois, moved his Resolutions, in favor of the War with Mexico—during the discussion of which, the House adjourned.

21 VI  In the Senate of the United States Daniel S. Dickinson the Senator from New York and John C. Calhoun, from South Carolina have offered opposite Resolutions respecting the termination of the War with Mexico. Dickinson in favor of extensive Acquisition of Territory—and Calhoun against extensive addition Territory— The Discussion of them was this day commenced and made the Order for the 4th. of January. In the House the call for Petitions was continued. Joshua R. Giddings, presented a memorial with 18 Citizens of the District of Columbia representing that the Slave Trade is now carried on, to a large extent, and praying that all Laws authorizing or sanctioning such Trade with the District may be repealed— Giddings moved to refer the memorial to the Committee on the Judiciary Clingman of North Carolina moved to lay the Petition on the Table, which was taken by yeas and nays—announced to be a tie 97 and 97. The Speaker then gave the casting vote against laying it on the Table— Chapman moved its reference to the Committee on the District of Columbia but Cobb of Georgia declared his to Debate the Memorial and it was laid over under the Rule. numerous Bills were introduced and notices of Bills to be introduced hereafter. I offered a Resolution which was adopted, that the Secretary of State Report to the House the state of the Claims of Aaron Leggett on the Government of Mexico decided under the Convention of the 11th. of April 1839. and such action as may have been had and the papers relating thereto in the Department of State since the Report upon them of the Committee on Foreign Affairs in August 1842. referring them for farther consideration to the Executive Branch of the Government— The House adjourned about three oclock—
